courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible
courses.description: This course is a survey of the books which made up the Hebrew Scriptures, and the lives of the people whom these books are about. It covers the period of the Patriarchs to the beginning of the Christian era within the context of the ancient Near Eastern world. This historical survey will also introduce students to the life and faith and literature of the Hebrew people. During the course, students are expected to read and become familiar with the Hebrew Scripture.
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics (Key concepts)

Introduction (Imaginative Remembering; Genre)

Torah, Genesis; (Myth, Legend and ANET)

Exodus, Leviticus; (Cult and Priestly school)

Numbers, Deuteronomy; (Law and Narrative)

Prophets, Joshua, Judges; (History and Deuteronomistic History)

1 and 2 Samuel, 1 and 2 Kings; (Prophet in Narrative)

Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel; (Literary Prophet and Their Social World)

Minor Prophets; (Twelve prophet as a book)

Writings, Psalms; (Poetry as Torah)

Job; Proverbs (Wisdom Literature)

Five Scrolls; (Hebrew Bible and the early Judaism)

Daniel, Ezra, Nehemiah, (2nd Temple Literature)

1 and 2 Chronicles; (The Rewritten Bible)

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Introduction to the New Testament
courses.description: This course is a survey of the New Testament Church, its life, faith and literature within the context of the Mediterranean world. During the course, students are expected to read and become familiar with the contents of the New Testament.
courses.learning_outcomes:
A) Knowledge Outcome:

- To give students a general understanding of the text of the New Testament, its methods of studies, its background and the issues involved.

B) Attitude Outcomes:

- To develop students’ appreciation of the New Testament text as well as the diversity of interpretation of it.

- To develop students’ ability to have a critical, yet sympathetic understanding of the New Testament.

- To develop students’ analytical mind in reading scholarly opinions.

Sessions 10-11:

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Prophetic Literature
courses.description: Exegesis of selected passages from Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel and the Twelve Prophets.
courses.course_syllabus:
Major concepts and topics to be covered:

1. The social world of the Hebrew prophets

This section covers the role of a prophet and the nature of prophecy in ancient Southwest Asia and Israel in relation to the social issues of its time.

2. The historical context

The Hebrew prophets will be situated in their signifying contexts from the Neo-Assyrian empire to the Persian empire.

3. Major sections and Individual books

The structure and literary features of prophetic literature of different major sections (the Former Prophets, the Latter Prophets, and the Twelve) and individual books will be adumbrated.

4. Critical approaches

Recent scholarship in a variety of critical methods will be discussed.

5. Theological notions

Major theological notions include covenant, messianism, inviolability of Zion, theodicy, retributive logic, universalism, ḥesed, and restoration.

6. Critical Issues

Critical issues include vaticinium ex eventu, the scheme of prophecy and fulfillment, social justice, the marital and sexual metaphor, divine violence, and historicity.

Course schedule:

Session 1:

Introduction to Prophetic Literature

Session 2:

The Social and Historical Context of the Hebrew Prophets

Session 3:

- What was a prophet?

- What was prophecy?

- Prophets and institutions

- Vaticinium ex eventu

Session 4:

- Prophetic genres

- Critical approaches and reading strategies

Session 5:

- Navi’im: The Former Prophets, the Latter Prophets, and the Twelve

- Female prophets

Session 6:

- The eighth-century prophets: Amos, Hosea, Micah, Proto-Isaiah

- Social critiques

Session 7:

- The late seventh-century minor prophets: Nahum, Zephaniah, Habakkuk, Obadiah

- Divine violence

Session 8:

- The early sixth-century Prophets: Jeremiah

Session 9:

- The early sixth-Century prophets: Ezekiel

- Marital and sexual metaphors

Session 10:

- Class Excursion: Poverty in Hong Kong

Session 11:

- The Persian prophets: Deutero-Isaiah and Trito-Isaiah

- Excursion debriefing

- Presentation of term-paper abstract

Session 12:

- The Persian prophets: Haggai, Zechariah, Malachi, Joel

Session 13:

- The fictional prophet: Jonah Concluding remarks

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Wisdom and the Psalms
courses.description: Exegesis of selected passages from Job, Proverb, Ecclesiates, Psalms and also from Wisdom passages from the prophets.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To learn the content of the Psalms and Wisdom Literature of the Hebrew bible.

2. To understand Hebrew Poetry and Hebrew Wisdom Theology, and their histories of interpretations.

3. To engage the biblical texts with various dimensions of the contemporary use of the texts within ecclesia and public life.
courses.course_syllabus:
Session 1:

\*Topics: Course Introduction, What is Wisdom?

\*Key concepts: Hokmah, Wisdom proper, Wisdom studies

Session 2

\*Topics:Overview on Wisdom Literature, Scholarship, Wisdom Theology; Introduction on Psalms, Hebrew Poetry and Parallelism

\*Key concepts: Hebrew Poetry, Parallelism, Wisdom Theology, Theological history, Reading Strategy, Context of emergence of Wisdom and Psalms

Session 3:

\*Topics: The Book of Proverbs (I)

\*Key concepts: Literary Structure, Traditional Wisdom, ‘Fear of the Lord’ , Lady Wisdom

Session 4:

\*Topics: The Book of Proverbs (II)

\*Key concepts: Themes and Theology in the book of Proverbs

Session 5:

\*Topics: Qoheleth (I)

\*Key concepts: Structure and Literary Features

Session 6:

\*Topics: Qoheleth (II)

\*Key concepts: Various themes in Qoheleth

Session 7:

\*Topics: Job (I)

\*Key concepts: Structure and Literary Features

Session 8:

\*Topics: Job (II)

\*Key concepts: Themes and Reception of Job

Session 9:

\*Topics: Introduction on Psalms

\*Key concepts: Genre, Structure, Canon and the Interpretation trends

Session 10:

\*Topics: Psalms (I)

\*Key concepts: Praise and Lament, Corporate and Individual

Session 11:

\*Topics: Psalms (II)

\*Key concepts: Collection and Editing of the Psalms: Songs of Korah; Psalms of Ascent

Session 12:

\*Topics: Psalms (III)

\*Key concepts: Acrostic Psalms, Wisdom Psalms, Creation Psalms; Theology of the Psalms

Session 13:

\*Conclusion (Presentation)

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Synoptic Gospels
courses.description: This course comprises a study of the synoptic problem, the characteristics, purpose and theology of the three Synoptic Gospels, and a detailed exegesis of selected passages from the Gospels both of Matthew and of Luke, including comparison with parallel passages in the Gospel according to Mark.
courses.learning_outcomes:
A) Knowledge Outcome:

- To give students a general understanding the text of the Synoptic Gospels, the methods of studies and the issues involved.

B) Attitude Outcomes:

- To develop students’ appreciation of the Synoptic Gospels as well as the diversity of their interpretation.

- To develop students’ ability to have a critical, yet sympathetic understanding of the text.

courses.title: Johannine Literature
courses.description: Study of selected passages from the Gospel according to John, the Epistles of John and Revelation (Apocalypse), including questions of authorship, purpose and main emphasis.
courses.course_syllabus:
Module I: Apocalypse of John

Since JohApc is in the periphery of the Johannine Literature, this course spares only two lectures for the introduction of this last book of the Bible. Its basic content will be sketched. Special attention will be paid to the dominant Christology of JohApc, namely the Lamb Christology. This Christology will be further interpreted in a modern context. Key concepts include: Lamb Christology, Martyr-Warrior.

Module II: Gospel of John

This course will discuss several major themes in the Gospel of John. Besides, participants will learn about the Forschungsgeschichte of these major themes. Methodologically, source criticism, feminist interpretation, tradition criticism, reception history, redaction criticism, textual criticism and social historical interpretation are frequently adopted. The receptions (including Chinese reception) of the Gospel of John in Art, Music and Film histories are concerned Key concepts include: Logos, Samaritan Woman, Son of Man, Paraclete, Beloved Disciple, Pericope Adulterae.

Module III: 1, 2 & 3 John

The basic content of each Johannine Epistles will be introduced. The instructor will attempt to reconstruct social contexts of these texts, in order to understand their significances in the Early Christianity. Key concepts include: Light, Righteousness, Love, Antichrist, hospitality.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Pauline Letters
courses.description: Study of selected passages from Romans, 1 and 2 Corinthians, Galatians, 1 and 2 Thessalonians, Ephesians, Philippians and Colossians, including general questions of date, authorship, setting, purpose and main theological emphasis.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes:

- To have the overview on the interpretation history of Pauline letters and their emphasis, development and trend.

- To have an overview on the key concepts and theological motifs of Pauline letters.

Skill Outcome:

- To be equipped with the necessary interpretation skills, based on the socio-rhetorical interpretation, to develop their own interpretation on Pauline letters.
courses.course_syllabus:
I) List of Topics

1. Problem in interpreting Pauline Letters

Learning the complication of interpreting Paul from historical and theological perspectives.

2. Basic concepts in interpreting Pauline Letters

Introducing various basic concepts in interpreting Paul including who Paul was, the context of Paul and the language Paul used, etc.

3. Interpretation History of Pauline Letters

Learning the development and differences in concerns and assumptions of various main stream interpretations beginning from the reformation.

4. Pauline Theological motifs

Learning the key theological motifs scholars generated from the undisputed Pauline letters.

5. Socio-rhetorical interpretation (SI)

Learning the methodology of SI and how it could help us to bring the economic “texture” into biblical exegesis.

6. Detail analysis of selected passages from Romans, Philemon and Philippians

Selected passages will be analyzed using the method and concepts introduced in the course

II) Course Schedule

Session 1:

Course Introduction + Problems in interpreting Paul

Session 2:

Basic concept in interpreting Pauline letters

Session 3:

Interpretation history of Pauline letters

Session 4:

Context of Paul (1): 2nd temple Judaism and New Perspective of Paul

Session 5:

Context of Paul (2): Social World of Paul including the Political and Economic situation of Roman Empire

Session 6:

Core Pauline theological motif 1 - Theology

Session 7:

Core Pauline theological motif 2 – Eschatology

Session 8:

Core Pauline theological motif 3 - Christology

Session 9:

Core Pauline theological motif 4 - Love

Session 10:

Interpretation Method: Socio-rhetorical Interpretation 2

Session 11:

Letter to Philemon: Demonstration of SRI application

Session 12:

Conclusion

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Early and Medieval Church
courses.description: The purpose of the course is to introduce the students to the historical and theological developments in the early and medieval church, from Jesus to the 15th century. The course offers a general knowledge of the theological and ecclesial development during the covered period and helps students get acquainted with different perspectives on church history and with issues that are still debated.
courses.learning_outcomes: The students will gain a general knowledge of the theological and ecclesial development during the covered period and get acquainted with different perspectives on church history and with issues that are still debated. The students will also develop sensitivity regarding the diversity of Christian faith expressions.
courses.course_syllabus:
Session 1 - The church in the first two centuries

Session 2 - Christianity and politics: Conflicts with the State; the extension of Christianity in the first three centuries

Session 3 - Challenges to the Faith in the Second Century and the Development of Early Catholic Theology

Session 4 - Christianity and culture: The encounter with Hellenist philosophy and the development of Patristic theology

Session 5 - Christianity becoming the religion of the empire: Constantine and his impact on the religious life of the Catholic Church

Session 6 - Theological and ecclesial controversies of the 4th Century: Donatism and Arianism

Session 7 - Theology and christological debates in the 5th century: The Council of Chalcedon; Augustine

Session 8 - Mission history in medieval times: the extension of Christianity and its inculturation in new contexts

Session 9 - Church and state: The growth of papal and ecclesial power through the middle ages and the conflict between emperor and

Session 10 - The history of a growing division: The churches in East and West on separate ways

Session 11 - The history of the other church: Revivalism, reform, and alternative Christian faith expression in the medieval time

Session 12 - Outward militancy and inward divisions in the high and late medieval time: the crusades, the inquisition and ecclesial divisions

Session 13 - A short introduction to medieval theology

courses.title: God, Creation and Eschatoloty
courses.description: A study of various ways of understanding of God, both traditional and contemporary; the doctrines of creation in their biblical, patristic and modern perspectives; and the doctrines of Eschatology. All with special emphasis on contemporary issues.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To review critically the concepts of God, creation and eschatology from a historical-theological approach.
2. To correlate the doctrines of God, creation and eschatology to other Christian doctrines.
3. To apply the knowledge and skill developed in the course creatively to Christian liturgical and ethical life.
4. To make formal presentation on the theme of the doctrine of God, creation and eschatology to the Christian communities

courses.description: In this course, we attempt to understand, in the light of developments up to and including the Second Vatican Council, what and how the Catholic Church conceives herself to be, and in such a conception, how she looks at the Bible, tradition and her sacramental life.
courses.learning_outcomes:
* Students will gain a general knowledge of the Catholic theological development throughout the recognized councils of the Catholic Church.
* The students will gain understanding of the particularities of Catholic theology in distinction to the theologies of other Christian traditions.
* The students will develop sensitivity regarding the diversity of Christian faith expressions.
* The students will gain historical depth in their theological reflection.
* The students will learn to understand doctrinal decisions of the Roman-Catholic tradition within their historical context and from there to critically evaluate these doctrinal decisions.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Systematic Theology I
courses.description: This course is an introduction to the nature and methodologies of Christian theology, with particular attention to the historical creeds of the Christian Churches.
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, the student is expected (a) to have a basic understanding of the history of Christian theology; (b) to understand the nature and roles of various factors that influences the formation of theology (especially the Bible, but also tradition, culture, theological language, etc.); (c) to have elementary knowledge of exemplary theological systems and methods; (d) to develop a basic competence in appreciating theological texts.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Pastoral Theology
courses.description: This course covers three areas: (1) the place of Pastoral Theology in theological studies and its uniqueness; (2) different types of Pastoral Theology and their aims; and (3) church models and pastoral emphases.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To understand what is Pastoral Theology with reflection from personal pastoral experience.

2. To construct Pastoral Theology from the Bible, church and Chinese cultural traditions.

3. To understand different emphases of Pastoral Theology from multiple perspectives and from histories of different denominations.
courses.course_syllabus:
課程綱要

一）何謂牧養神學？

二）牧者為中心的牧養神學
\*牧者的角色：牧人？羊？先知？祭司？領袖？僕人？教師？神學家？

\*牧者的功能與責任：餵養？照顧？宣講？ 禮儀？領導？行政？教導？輔導？探訪？ 佈道？栽培？訓練？社會活動？社會服務？

\*牧養範圍有何界線？

三）牧者與成長
\*牧者的危機

\*牧者成長的攔阻

四）信徒(需要)為中心的牧養神學

\*信徒需要些什麼？

\*對信徒有什麼期望？

五）信仰群體為中心的牧養神學
\*教會存在的意義與功能

\*教會的成長和發展

六）世界為中心的牧養神學
\*在世與不屬世

\*天國的使命

七）教會與發展
\*聖禮、崇拜

\*訓練與栽培

\*教會增長與植堂

八）世界與個人
\*社會、政治

\*生寄死歸

課節安排

第一節：牧者的角色

第二節：何謂牧養神學

第三節：牧者的本質、功能與責任、牧者為中心的牧養神學

第四節：牧者的能力、恩賜、靈性、心態和心理健康

第五節：讀書報告分享

第六節：個人牧養、生寄死歸

第七節：聖經中教會的諸形象、教會為中心 的牧養神學

第八節：使命為中心的牧養神學

第九節：植堂策略個案研討

第十節：教會領導、組織文化在教會群體中的協同效應與信徒運動的推展

第十一節：崇拜、聖禮、聖曆與牧養

第十二節：教會增長研討

第十三節：多元化的牧養神學、牧養神學的再思

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Foundation of Religious Education
courses.description: This course is an introduction to religious education. Some of the central issues in religious education will be raised, including what kind of education it is, why is such education necessary, when and how is one to be educated, for what and to what extent, etc. Attempts will be made to relate religious education to other disciplines such as theology, education, psychology, sociology, philosophy.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To have a critical understanding of the current discussion of religious education as human’s education, spiritual education, confessional religious education and others.
2. To acquire an analytical skill to evaluate the socio-political context, the philosophy and the implementation of religious education in different faith-based schools in Hong Kong.
3. To understand different religious traditions and creatively develop appropriate pedagogy for religious education.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Hebrew Bible Exegesis
courses.description: A continuation of the study of Hebrew grammar and the reading of selected passages from the Old Testament in Hebrew.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes:
(1) know how to use the reference tools needed to do Hebrew exegesis
(2) know how to use BHS and BHQ
(3) analyze syntax with a given Hebrew text
(4) know how to use Hebrew Grammar Books
(5) explain how to do textual criticism with a given Hebrew text
(6) apply exegetical guidelines to exegete a given Hebrew text
(7) recognize how syntax, textual criticism and traditions can affect the interpretation of texts
(8) know how to make use of concordances, lexicons, and dictionaries for Hebrew exegesis
(9) analyze and evaluate commentaries

Attitude Outcomes:
(1) develop an appreciation for the long history and tradition of the transmission of texts
(2) be confident in using appropriate tools for specific needs to interpreting texts
(3) be confident in reading and exegeting Biblical Hebrew texts
(4) inculcate respect for meticulous scholarship to interpret a text
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Exegesis of the Hebrew Bible
2. Textual Criticism
A. The Masoretic Text in BHS and BHQ
B. The Dead Sea Scrolls (DSS)
C. Selecting a reading
3. Hebrew Grammar and Syntax
4. Appreciating Commentaries
5. How to do Word study
6. Exegesis and the Historical Context
7. Literary Criticism
8. The Other Methods
9. The Exegesis Process

courses.description: A study of elementary New Testament Greek vocabulary and grammar to prepare students to read the New Testament in its original Greek form.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite(s): THEO3215(1215) or THEO5303
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes:

On the successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:

1. master the essential Greek morphology and syntax and a handful vocabulary of New Testament Greek.

Attitude Outcomes:

Throughout the learning process, students are expected to:

1. develop a regular revision practice;
2. develop a positive attitude to face difficulties in learning; and

3. develop an initiative to help others and seek help from others by means of group study.
courses.course_syllabus: This course is a continuation of New Testament Greek I. It provides students with an introduction to the essential elements to New Testament Greek. Students will master different aspects of Greek morphology and syntax and acquire a substantial reading vocabulary. In order to enhance learning, the course employs both deductive and inductive methods.
courses.feedback_evaluation: A tailored made mid-term course evaluation and end-of- term university wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through the online learning platform or personal meeting with instructor and/ or tutors are always welcomed.
courses.recommended_readings: Dobson, John H. Learn New Testament Greek. Grand Rapids, MI: Baker Academic, 32005 (1988).

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Biblical Hebrew I
courses.description: This course, and the sequel Biblical Hebrew II in the next semester, are designed to enable students to read Biblical Hebrew. In this course, Biblical Hebrew I, students learn the alphabets to the basic forms of Hebrew sentences. Students not only learn how to read simple sentences from the Hebrew bible, but also learn to identify different parts of speech, and basic grammar. Students will also learn some Hebrew songs which accompany the lessons. This course follows closely to its textbook, Learn Biblical Hebrew by John H. Dobson (2005). Biblical Hebrew I will cover Lessons 1-13.
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes
(1) recite and write down from memory the Hebrew alphabets, vowels and their transliterations
(2) pronounce and read Hebrew words
(3) recite from memory Genesis 1:1 (D 2.4; p. 18); Deuteronomy 6:4-5 (D 5.6; p. 55); the songs: We welcome you (D 1.13 Q5; p. 16) and Blessed are You (D 5.9 Q6; p. 58)
(4) memorize at least 350 Hebrew words perfectly by the end of the course
(5) recognize words and identify them correctly as nouns, verbs, prepositions, constructs, suffixes, adjectives, infinitives or participles
(6) identify the forms of questions, commands and requests
(7) parse a given word
(8) list the functions of adjectives, participles, infinitives, prefix and suffix conjugations, waw consecutive conjugation as well as concepts of perfective and non-perfective

Attitude Outcomes
(1) develop an interest and respect for the historical and cultural development of the Hebrew language from its paleo-Hebrew script until its Aramaic script, and the modern Hebrew language
(2) appreciate the distinctiveness of the Biblical Hebrew language
(3) cultivate an interest to read Biblical Hebrew texts

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Biblical Hebrew II
courses.description: This course, a sequel to Biblical Hebrew I, will continue to follow the textbook, Learn Biblical Hebrew by John H. Dobson (2005), covering Lessons 12–25. It will cover all the binyanim of Hebrew as well as understanding concepts of Hebrew syntax, function of prepositions and the principles of translating narratives and poetry and attempt a few exercises. In particular, we shall read the Masoretic text of the book of Jonah (a narrative with a poem) with the help of the Lexicons/Dictionaries and other Bible aids.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite(s): THEO3217(1213) or THEO5301
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes
The students will be competent in the following abilities:
(a) recognize every component in the parts of speech learned in THEO 3217
(b) identify the binyanim and functions of all verbs
(c) recall the forms and functions of the prepositions and particles
(d) identify, recognize at least 500 of the most common Biblical Hebrew words found in the Hebrew Bible
(e) search words in the Biblical Hebrew dictionaries and lexicons and explain the entries, in particular the BDB Lexicon.
(f) parse and translate given phrases/sentences and the book of Jonah
(g) use the parsing tools of Bible Works 10

Attitude Outcomes
The students will:
(a) be confident to read a Biblical Hebrew passage on their own with the necessary tools
(b) develop the habit of reading Biblical Hebrew passages
(c) appreciate the basic tasks to do exegesis and interpretation

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: History of Christianity in China
courses.description: The development of Christian thought and institutions in China.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students shall obtain a general knowledge of the major historical developments of Christianity in China from the seventh century to present.

2. Students are expected to forge their own understanding and evaluation towards the key issues emerged when Christianity encountered the Chinese contexts.

3. Students shall get acquainted with different perspectives/models of Christianity in China, as well as with the issues which are still debatable nowadays.

4. Through both the lecture teachings and tutorial discussions, students shall develop a historical and theological sense towards the diversity of Christian expressions in China and are expected to critically reflect on the process of Christianity indigenisation/contextualisation in Chinese history.
courses.course_syllabus:
第1節:

導論：中國基督教史研究概述（1949 年之前的基督新教）

第2節:

十字蓮花：東方教會流行中國記

第3節:

合儒超儒：天主教與中華帝國的相遇

第4節:

福臨中華：基督新教傳教事業的建立與發展

第5節:

風潮中奮起：民族主義、非基督教運動衝擊下的在華基督新教

第6節:

安身立命：中國教會自我意識的求索

第7節:

道成肉身：中國民間基督教的興起

第8節:

真理·自由·服務：在華教會學校的興衰

第9節:

人格救國：基督新教與中國社會

第10節:

亂世浮生：戰火洗禮下的中國基督教

第11節:

誰與共舞：政權更替後的中國基督教

第12-13節:

學生報告

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: History of Christianity in Hong Kong
courses.description: This course aims at an in-depth study about the historical development of Christianity (including Protestant and Catholic churches) in Hong Kong since the beginning of the British rule. This study will emphasize the role of Christianity in the wider context of the history of Hong Kong, with special focus on the relationship between Christianity and Hong Kong society (education, medical care, social service, social action, etc.) and various issues arising from these areas.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To assist students to understand the history of Protestant Christianity in Hong Kong.

2. To assist students to acquaint the methods of conducting research on local church history.

3. To develop and affirm students’ identity towards local church history.
courses.course_syllabus:
一、導論：從大歷史看香港基督教
二、開基與拓荒：香港基督教的建立（1841 - 1860）

三、華南與香港：發展與自立（1860 - 1936）

四、難民與福音（1937 - 1960’s）

五、本土教會的形成（1970’s - ）

六、傳教與教育：香港教會辦學
七、天國與社會：基督教與社會參與
八、上帝與該撒：政教關係在香港
九、福音與文化：西洋、中華、本土的交融
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Theology and Feminism
courses.description: This course will survey feminist theory, its use in feminist theologies, and implications of selected issues in feminist theory for theology in general.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Delineate the historical oppression of the female gender in Church History and the Judeo-Christian traditions.
2. Review and describe the theological history of women’s identity, status and role in the family, church and society at large.
3. Analyze and criticize how theologies are formulated against the female gender in Christian history until today. Evaluate how formulations of the God-talk and other aspects of theology are also influenced by such theologies. Comment and specify the abuse, violence, subversion and impoverishment of the female gender and their relation to ecology.
4. Research and reconstruct female presence in history and Christian sources.
5. Describe and explain what constitutes gender, sexuality, and female embodiment, and draw implications on these discourses in the academia.
6. Construct practical frameworks to educate and raise awareness of the oppression, and also propose ideas how to promote a just and righteous community of faith and society.
courses.course_syllabus: The course aims at exposing students to a broad perspective and discussion about the dynamic relationship between theology and feminism. Students will encourage to reexamine the ways in which the Western Judeo-Christian religious traditions have profoundly influenced our understanding of God and gender and to study feminist interpretations of God-talk, redemption, spirituality, and church.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Local Church Study
courses.description: The main aim of this course is to help students to acquire a basic understanding of the local churches. The contents include brief introductions to historical, theological as well as sociological dimension of the local churches. Basic knowledge of congregational studies and methods of church analysis will also be introduced.
courses.learning_outcomes:
知識方面：
從歷史角度初步了解本地新教之發展與現況
把握本地新教堂會的社會學及神學實況
學習分析影響著本地新教堂會發展之幾個因素
認識堂會研究之方法及方法論基礎
態度方面：
對堂會發展與現況持批判而開放的態度
更關心本地堂會發展
技巧方面：
能初步以堂會研究之方法去分析本地教會議題

courses.title: Homiletics

meetings.instructor:
Dr. LI Kwan Hung Leo, 
Professor YIP Ching Wah Francis

courses.description: This course will cover: (1) the principles, construction and technique in preaching; and (2) the content and message of a sermon in the contemporary world. Student’s preaching will be videotaped and discussed for improvement of technique and content.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To understand the principle of preaching on theological topics.

2. To understand the integration of different types of preaching and the way of preparation.

3. To learn and practice the techniques and styles in delivering a sermon.
courses.course_syllabus:
一、 課程評估
分享／引論
聽道／講道經驗及心得
何謂講道學（Homiletics）？

講道的構成因素——真道、表達、使命、講者、聽眾、技巧、權柄

二、 真道
何謂道？
聖經與道
宣講與教導之不同
道與行

三、講章的分類
專題式講道
經文式講道
釋經講道

四、講章的性質
佈道
培靈
奮興
牧養
婚禮
喪追思
紀念日
聖曆及特別主日

五、經文的選擇與運用
用一段經文的好處
選擇經文要留意的地方
如何運用經文

六、如何決定主旨
主旨的必要
主旨的選擇

七、如何決定題目

八、講章的結構
分段與大綱
引論、本論、結論

九、導言
三個目的

十、例證
講道的天窗

十一、結論與應用
應用的重要性
應用的三個成份
應用的動機

十二、講章的準備和組成的步驟
探索期
專注期
講章的組合
最後的準備

十三、講道的技巧
講者的素質與風格
講章的表達與演繹

十四、學生試講

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Denominational Tradition and Polity
courses.description:
This course is a study of the Protestant denominations that have made an impact in Hong Kong. The theological traditions, liturgies, polity, mission strategies and models of Anglican, Church of Christ in China, Methodist and Tsung Tsin Church will be studied.

Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times.
courses.course_syllabus:
第一節
難以捉摸的衞斯理約翰（ John Wesley)

第二節
十六至十八世紀的英國宗教社會與政治狀況

第三節
獻呈基督— 衞斯理宗的宣教佈道（ Prof.Jack. Jackson)

第四節
十八世紀循道衞理宗福音復興運動歷史

第五節
神學核心— 救恩階梯（ 一）

第六節
神學核心— 救恩階梯（ 二）

第七節
蒙恩途徑— 問責任性的信仰群體

第八節
個人與群體的生命禮儀— 靈修、崇拜與聖禮（ 一）

第九節
個人與群體的生命禮儀— 靈修、崇拜與聖禮（ 二）

第十節
牧職的源起與發展— 遊行傳道、本地傳道、聖職制度

第十一節
窮人的福音— 與窮苦者同行的社會關懷

第十二節
神學四柱及時代回應

第十三節
香港循道衞理會的發展與傳承

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Liturgics
courses.description: The history, theory and practice of public worship.
courses.learning_outcomes: The course aims at equipping students with the understanding of the history and theology of the sacred worship, which include the development of the sacred worship, the notion of liturgical time, of ecclesiastical year, of sacred space, of Monastic and Cathedral office, of the liturgy of the hours. It also helps student to gain a critical understanding on various liturgical terms, liturgical vessels, books and vestments. Contextualization of liturgy in Chinese/Hong Kong contexts will also be discussed.
courses.course_syllabus:
Session 1

Corporate Worship and Church Life; Worship in Truth and Spirit; Worship as Dialogue.

Session 2

Design and Discharge in Worship. The Study of 1 Corinthians 14;
The Planning of the Order of Service; Writing of corporate prayers and mediation for the lectionary.

Session 3

Worship as Offering; Old Testament Sacrifices, Levitical Priesthood and the Church as a Royal Priesthood.

Session 4

Time as Communication: The Christian Calendar; the Lectionary.

Session 5

Corporate Worship in Light of The Book of Revelation

Session 6

Space as Communication; Christian Art and Worship.

Session 7

Worship as Pastoral Care: The Funeral and the Wedding Service; Special Occasions.

Session 8

The Sacraments and Corporate Worship—The Rite of Initiation-Holy Baptism.

Session 9

The Sacraments and Corporate Worship—The Rite of Continuation— Eucharist

Session 10

Worship as a Drama—The Western Roman Catholic tradition; Vatican II Liturgical Reform; Worship as a Journey--The Orthodox Church tradition.

Session 11

The Protestant Tradition: The Normative and Regulative Principles of Liturgical Reforms: Reformed, Lutheran, Anglican.

Session 12

The Non-conformists: Quakers, Free Church, and Charismatic; The Seekers- friendly services.

Session 13

The Function of Congregational Singing in Corporate Worship; Hymnology

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Preaching
courses.description:
Through instructions and discussion, students are given guidance in their composition and delivery of sermons. Special emphasis will be given to Biblical exposition, progression of thoughts, flow of feelings, use of illustrations, relevance, and delivery styles. Each student is expected to deliver a full-length sermon in front of other students two to three times a semester and hand in the relevant scripts at the same time.

Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Prerequisite: THEO3241.
courses.learning_outcomes: 本科目主要目的為鍛鍊講章的撰寫及宣講的技巧，特別著重聖經的闡釋、思路的發展、信息的凝聚、情感的表達、引寓的運用、處境的適切、宣道的風格及真道的應用。老師會就個別同學的表現提供批評指導，以改進同學講道的質素。

觀摩與評論

第4節：

宣講微技巧

講章類別的撰寫與演繹：釋經講道(Expository preaching)

宣講與修辭技巧

在危機中的宣講

宣講與多媒體應用

向不同群體的宣講方式

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Death and Dying
courses.description: This course is designed to provide students with an opportunity to deepen their understanding of the issues and feelings surrounding death and dying. It is also designed to allow students to develop skill and sensitivity in ministering to others.
courses.learning_outcomes:
A. Knowledge Outcomes

1. To enhance the ability of individuals to formulate, analyze, and deepen one’s own opinion on death-related practices and ethical issues.

2. To heighten sensitivity about cultural variations in dying, death and grief.

B. Skill Outcome

1. To have the ability integrating the dying with the living.

C. Attitude Outcome

1. To strengthen a spirituality of hope and courage to face personal aspect of death.

Good Bye

Life after Death: Silence Teacher Scheme (visit)

Good Life: Suicide

Death, Violence and Catastrophe

Session 12:

Death Education

courses.title: Ecumenics
courses.description: The study of various types of theological thinking including Fundamentalism, Pentecostalism, Evangelicalism, Catholicism, Liberalizm, Orthodoxy, etc.; the history of the ecumenical movement and issues in ecumenical theological thinking.
courses.learning_outcomes: The students will be able to utilize the analytical framework of denominational and post-denominational distinctions to critically review and understand the present-day ecclesial landscape. They will consolidate their systematic-theological knowledge through recognition of diverse spiritual actualizations and they will be able to apply the learnt analytical skills across the ecclesial expressions in the political and social and in the liturgical and spiritual expression of the church.
courses.course_syllabus:
This interdisciplinary course will consider the subject of "World Christianity" and its potential impact on churches and families of churches in different contexts. As a course in ecumenics, we will integrate a wide range of disciplines, including history, theology, social science and cultural studies. A major part of the course involves teaching interdisciplinarity as a method in addressing ideas and issues in theology and world Christianity. This is a relatively new approach in theological studies which may be applied to other courses in other disciplines.

The course will address common issues and theological themes: mission and ecumenism; Christianity in a world of religions; Christology; secularization; the environment; economic justice, gender, always bearing in mind their implications for churches in particular places, especially Hong Kong, as well as their global dimension. The two are necessarily related.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Issues Facing Churches Today
courses.description: Issues facing the Church in relation to the ideologies, religions, and cultural and sociological conditions in the contemporary world with special emphasis on the processes of secularization, modernization and urbanization.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To adopt multi-disciplinary approaches to identify, analyze and evaluate the contemporary issues facing churches.

2. To extend the knowledge and skill developed in the course for making critical understanding on other issues.

3. To develop appropriate manner, honest exchange of idea and skill to solve problems in group discussions.
courses.course_syllabus: The church is called by God to the ministry of reconciliation and sent to the world to challenge the idols of death, on the one hand and witness to the God of life, on the other. This is about Christian mission. This course focuses on the theme of peace and justice in worldwide politics and its relation to Christian mission. Nine cases are selected for mission studies. The following questions would be kept on asking in each case: On what basis can we discern God’s mission in the midst of social incidents? What does God’s mission contribute to human rights? What are the ethical, missiological and theological considerations for Christian action? How are people’s movement and resistance to be interpreted and evaluated theologically? What are and would be Christian reconciling initiatives? What is Christian spirituality in mission? What would be a contextual or ‘incarnated’ ecclesiology like? What is the relation between the church as God’s people and the church as a cultural, social and political entity?

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Faculty Student Seminar I
courses.description: This course aims to develop practical research and academic writing skills of students. They are required to choose a subject for a paper, to create a logical structure, and to construct their own arguments academically. Their papers will be presented at the seminars. Chosen topics of the paper should be related to theological areas such as systematic theology, biblical studies, church history, practical theology, gender theology and so on. Nevertheless, students are encouraged to discuss current issues and subjects of other disciplines relating to the modern world from a theological perspective. Students’ performances will be primarily assessed by their written papers and presentations, but also by their participation in the discussion session. They will be evaluated on their ability to think theologically, that is, to reflect upon major theological and social issues, to define current issues in theological terms, and theological issues from the perspective of other disciplines.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes: This course will enhance students’ research skills, critical thinking and independent learning. The former will be achieved through the students’ own discovery of a subject that concerns academic interests and is feasible within the time and word limit, reviewing certain academic discussion of their chosen subjects, creating appropriate research methodologies, searching for and selecting materials, making sound judgements, engaging in meaningful dialogue with the newly-discovered information and former knowledge, and finally drawing up a sensible conclusion. This learning process is totally dependent on students’ own initiatives, creativity, sensitivity to theological and other issues, diligence, writing skills, as well as the awareness of self-limitations which can be reflected by their actively seeking advice from course instructors and through discussion with student peers. Students will be encouraged to move out of their own ‘comfort zones’ in order to critically evaluate new information and knowledge and apply this to the contemporary context.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. academic writing style
2. structure of academic papers
3. developing a good research topic & title
4. developing a thesis statement and defend it
5. how to write an Introduction
6. literature review and the ways to argue for a research gap/agenda
7. arguing theologically and reasonably
8. writing an abstract
9. Chicago-style citation
10. academic honesty

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Graduate Project I
courses.description: Graduate project is a capstone for theological students in their final year to integrate their learning across theological disciplines through the completion of an action project. It is driven by the interests and experiences of the students. Under the supervision of a faculty member, the student proposes and completes a project with a critical and reflective theological evaluation of the practice of ministry in the Church and/or the society. In order to complete the capstone project, the student has to take THEO5009, 5010 and 5011 as a whole in his/her/hir final year.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.course_syllabus:
Graduate Project welcomes a variety of creative project proposals that aim to integrate the student's passions and raison d'etre with his/her/hir unique embodiment of text, spirituality, and culture. It could be an original, creative work of art that demonstrates Christian aesthetics or a practical theological project that addresses a specific issue in ministry, engaging in dialogue with relevant analyses of contemporary culture(s) and Christian tradition(s) (themes, symbols, community, literature, etc). Through Graduate Project, the student is expected to demonstrate his/her/hir ability to integrate academic, practical, and spiritual knowledge/understanding to address a real-world issue. In order to facilitate the learning process, culminating assignments are distributed throughout the academic year. The core syllabus includes the elements below:

1. Project Proposal Writing: Among other things, project objectives, rationale, time frames, delivery, intended outcomes, and evaluation methods.
2. Project Report: After completing the project, the student is required to submit a written report of approximately 5000 words that includes an evaluation of the project's goal achievement and suggestions for future improvements. Furthermore, the report must include a theological reflection on the project via a critical dialogue between Christian tradition(s), the student's own foundational theological assumptions, and the project context. The student is also required to submit project products or deliverables such as PowerPoint slides, educational resources, or video of an event, in addition to the written report, to demonstrate his/her/hir performance and creativity.
3. Presentation at a "Theology Salon": At the end of the academic year, students are invited to present their projects at the Theology Salon, where students and teachers engage in a critical theological discussion of the students' project accomplishments.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Theology and Contemporary Critical Theories
courses.description:
Graham Ward, Regius Professor of Divinity at the University of Oxford, once remarked, "theology’s business has always been the transgression of boundaries. It is a discourse which requires other discourses for its very possibility." In this light, theological study is inherently interdisciplinary. Also, theologians are increasingly getting involved in praxis, which calls for them to have the expertise to critically examine the social, cultural, and political dimensions of everyday life. This course addresses these two aspects of theological study and focuses on the various ways theology can engage with contemporary critical theories in order to theologically analyze a society along the three media of speech, money, and power, as described by Jürgen Habermas.

The course selectively covers the following contemporary critical theories and topics: the Frankfurt School and Dialectical Thinking in the Marxist traditions; Michel Foucault's Theories of Power, Knowledge, Truth, Subjectivity, and Ethics; Postcolonialism and Decoloniality; Critical Theories of Everyday Resistance; Critical Historiography; Critical Theory; Feminism and Queer Theory. In addition to a survey of the various approaches to critical theories, selected prominent critical theorists from each approach will be discussed. The theological implications of these theories will be examined through the lens of selected social issues and phenomena. Students will be required to conduct a theologically critical analysis of selected issues in their home society by adopting one of the critical perspectives. This course weaves together analytical approaches from the two disciplines to provide a theologically critical understanding of contemporary social issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
* *Upon successful completion of this course, students will acquire the ability to:**

* understand the fundamentals of the methodology of critical theory, its historical trajectory, its relevance in the present day, and its theological implications in the study of society.
* utilize critical theory's tools to theologize how dominant social forces are manifesting in the world today.
* critically consider the possibilities and constraints of social progress from a theological perspective in the present day.
* conduct mini studies on pressing social issues, utilizing theological and critical perspectives from across disciplines.

* *Students will develop the following skills:**

* critical theological reasoning, especially concerning contemporary social issues.
* interdisciplinary skills required to analyse the world using theologically relevant critical theories.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The Origin and Basic Philosophy of Critical Theories and Marxism

1a. Class struggle, the critique of capitalism, and ideology in the Marxist traditions

1b. The Frankfurt School and dialectical thinking—Horkheimer, Adorno, Marcuse, Benjamin, psychoanalysis, etc.

1c. Habermas’ theory of communicative rationality

1d. Theological implications of the Frankfurt School

2. Michel Foucault's Critical Theories

2a. Foucauldian power, knowledge, truth, and subjectivity

The topics below will be covered selectively in different years:

3. Postcolonialism and Decoloniality

4b. James C. Scott’s everyday forms of resistance

4c. Michel de Certeau’s practice of everyday life

4d. Asef Bayat’s politics of subaltern and “informal people”

4e. Theologizing as everyday resistance

5. Critical Historiography

5a. Paul Ricœur and narrative

5b. Hayden White’s metahistory

5c. New historicism

5d. Theology, historiography, and politics of historical writing

6b. Major concerns of different schools of feminism

6d. Queer and identity politics

6f. Foucault’s theses about regimes of sexuality

6g. Derrida’s deconstructionism and the binary opposition of male/female, homosexuality/heterosexuality

6h. Judith Butler’s theses on gender as performativity

6i. Feminist theology and Queer theology

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Theology and Empirical Research Methods
courses.description:
“Experience” and reflection on it have always been a concern for theologians, despite the diversity of theological traditions that prioritize various aspects of the formative factors for theology in different ways. In addition, contemporary theologians and church leaders share a growing concern for praxis that transforms the world and the church. All of this necessitates that theologians comprehend experience not only on a philosophical and conceptual level, but also as inherently concrete and social. Consequently, theologians are becoming increasingly interested in distinctive categories of empirical data pertinent to theology and in distinctive research methodologies pertinent to the analysis of these data. This is especially true of practical theologians and empirical theologians, though it is not exclusive to them. In this light, as stated by the editors of the Eerdmans series of Studies in Ecclesiology and Ethnography, if theology is to have impact on the church and world today, theologians must learn to utilize empirical research tools to provide more accurate, disciplined, and contextually-grounded research.

This course thus exposes students to a variety of empirical research methods and data analytic tools that will help them understand, evaluate, and conduct empirical research relevant to theological studies. The primary emphasis will be on qualitative approaches, but students will also learn how to read quantitative research reports critically. It aims to provide students with a foundation for integrating theological inquiry and empirical research in a manner that not only maintains the integrity of both disciplines but also employs social scientific methods in a manner that is "theological all the way through," as Helen Cameron has stated. Students will be required to conduct a mini-study on selected issues in their home society/church by adopting one of the empirical research methods.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon successful completion of this course, student should be able to:

* explain the role and importance of empirical research in theology.
* exhibit a critical understanding of empirical research methods and their application to theological inquiry.
* explain why a particular empirical method is preferable for answering a particular theological research question.
* differentiate and explain various qualitative research methodologies.
* develop open-ended questions for an in-depth oral interview and focus group interview.
* conduct qualitative data analysis manually and with software like NVivo.
* explain the relationship between measurement and concept.
* critically comprehend basic statistical language.
* explain which ethical considerations must be incorporated into empirical research.
* formulate a theological problem that is amenable to qualitative research and develop an appropriate research design.
* reflect theologically on empirical findings and incorporate empirical findings into normative discourse.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Modes of interaction between theological inquiries and empirical research methods

1A. The history of the use of social scientific methods in theological research

1B. Examples of how empirical research can be used in theological inquiries—empirical theology and practical theology

1C. The principle of "theological all the way through"

2. Qualitative approaches to inquiry (e.g., narrative, phenomenology and its variants, grounded theory and constructivist grounded theory, ethnography, case study, action research, etc.)

3. Methods in qualitative research

3A. How to ask well-constructed, focused questions

3B. The role of theoretical framework in different kinds of qualitative research

3C. Data collection

3Ci. Methods of sampling

3Cii. Qualitative interviewing: structured, semi-structured, unstructured interview; individual in-depth interview and focus group interview, etc.

3Ciii. Field observations, ethnography, digital ethnography, etc.

3D. Qualitative data analysis, interpretation, and presentation

3Di. Various types of coding, thematic analysis, theorization, and standard computer-assisted data analysis software such as NVivo

3Dii. Strategies of data interpretation; the issue of trustworthiness, validity, and generalization

4. The fundamentals of various quantitative research facets: key-terms and design, research questions, hypothesis, operationalization of concepts, instruments, questionnaire design, population, sample, common types of data analysis (univariate, bivariate, and multivariate analysis), and standard data analysis software such as SPSS, etc.

5. How to critically read quantitative research reports

6. The use of mixed methods

7. Research ethics

8. Theological reflection on empirical findings

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Ecumenics
courses.description: The course studies the present landscape of unity and differences among Christians, in particular cross-denominational movements like ecumenism, evangelicalism, and the Pentecostal-charismatic movement. The course analyzes these movements and related ones like independentism, fundamentalism, and others, and considers how these different movements interact with social contexts, in what sense these movements have an ecumenical dimension, and how far they can be understood as genuine forms of contextualized Christian faith.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity, MA in Theological Studies and MA in Christian Studies
courses.learning_outcomes: The students will be able to utilize the analytical framework of denominational and post-denominational distinctions to critically review and understand the present-day ecclesial landscape. They will consolidate their systematic-theological knowledge through recognition of diverse spiritual actualizations and they will be able to apply the learnt analytical skills across the ecclesial expressions in the political and social and in the liturgical and spiritual expression of the church.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Issues Facing Churches Today
courses.description: The goal of the course is to explore what kind of issues churches are facing in contemporary world, to reflect and to recommend how churches respond to these challenges. The goal is not about the concern of survival, but about the concern of mission, Missio Dei. Apart from a lot of issues surrounding us, different agendas of churches (or denominations) make the selection of the issues for discussion more difficult. Due to this, the design of the course adopts an interactive approach, that is to say, we come to discuss, decide and analyze the issues for study. We work in a group, not individual, although assessment is individually based. At the same time, methodologies of theological reflection are introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To adopt multi-disciplinary approaches to identify, analyze and evaluate the contemporary issues facing churches.
2. To extend the knowledge and skill developed in the course for making critical understanding on other issues.
3. To develop appropriate manner, honest exchange of idea and skill to solve problems in group discussions.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Women in World Missions
courses.description: In the context of Christianity as a worldwide movement, the majority of church members are women. Since the early 1800s, women have led in cross-cultural ministries of service, witness, evangelism, and philanthropic works. In order to understand these phenomena, this course will explore the context, nature, theory, and issues relating to women in world missions with particular focus on the 19th century to the present. In addition to examining important global issues for women in missions, it will cover women encounter with local culture through which to explore any selective appropriation of Western Christianity from intercultural perspective.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies or MA Theological Studies
courses.learning_outcomes: Students will be able to identify and analyze some of the critical concepts, methods, and debates in women and World missions; to discover historical agencies of both two categories of women, i.e., non-Western women and women missionaries; and to become aware of any gender factors shaping our understandings of mission theologies and practices.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Christianity and Ecology
courses.description: This course explores the ways in which Christianity is responding to environmental issues. Environmental crisis raises economic, social, biological, legal, moral and theological concerns. This course interprets Christian responses to environmental problems from an interdisciplinary perspective. This course will introduce students to the major theologies of ecology and strategies for action.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students are able to demonstrate knowledge of major themes and perspectives that exist at the intersection of Christianity and ecology.
2. Students are able to critically assess the history and development of Christian thought on the environment.
3. Students are able to apply the methodologies and concepts learned in this course to environmental and religious problems in creative and pragmatic ways.
4. Students are able to present their analysis of the main themes of the course and a well-argued articulation of their own perspective on these issues.
courses.feedback_evaluation:
An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students' comments and feedback on the course
through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Selected Reading of the Hebrew Bible
courses.description: This course selects one major script or some minor scripts of the Hebrew Bible for studies. Issues including textual criticism, authorship and readership, sources, themes and theology will be discussed. The interpretations of these issues by scholars will also be incorporated.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Describe the historical contexts and explain the purpose of composition of the biblical book/s.
2. Comment critically on the complex relationship between composition and readership of the book/s.
3. Review past scholarship of interpretations for the specific book or passage.
4. Review and analyse the biblical book/passage using the different methods of exegesis/interpretation taught in class.
5. Formulate and theorise the ideologies/theologies in/of the biblical book/passage.
6. Reflect and articulate the relevance of the academic study to today's contexts.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Second Temple Period
2. Persian colonization and Yehud province
3. Different Social Identities of the Jews: Exclusive and Inclusive Jewish Community
4. Aramaic Sections of the Hebrew Bible
5. Temple worship and Temple Personnel in the Persian Period
6. Prophecy in the Second Temple period
7. The new understanding of Historiography and its ideology
8. Ezra-Nehemiah-Chronicles as Christian Scripture
courses.feedback_evaluation: Two course evaluations will be conducted. The first will be done midway through the course which is tailored to facilitate better progress through the course. The second will be conducted by the university wide exercise.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Extracanonical Literature
courses.description: This course deals with the ancient texts ranging from about 3rd BCE to about 3rd CE and including the Old Testament, Pseudepigraphies as well as the New Testament Apocrypha. Introductory issues, such as authorship, language and manuscripts are included. The theologies of the literature, which represented different stages of the development of different sects or schools and contributed to the development of Early Christianity, will be studied.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity and MA in Theological Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
Expected Knowledge Outcomes
1. Categorize different extracanonical texts;
2. Compare and contrast New Testament symbols with those extracanonical variations and their intertextuality (i.e. Rezeptionsgeschichte);
Expected Skills Outcome
3. Analyze Sozial-, Literatur-, & Religionsgeschichte of Early Christianity (or Christianities) behind primary extracanonical texts; (\* This also serve as a preparation of key research skills for graduate work in advanced biblical studies)
Expected Attitude Outcome
4. Deepen their critical and yet sympathetic understanding of extracanonical Christian traditions in our contemporary contexts and appraise their contributions on widening the horizon of biblical interpretation as well as in shaping different cultures.
courses.course_syllabus:
Extracanonical Literature in light of Canonization, *Literaturgeschichte*, Cultural Memory, Attention (*Aufmerksamkeit*), and Intertextuality
Deuterocanonical Books as Agents of Cultural Memory in Mainstream Church Traditions
Apocrypha I: Prayer of Manasseh / Letter of Jeremiah / Baruch / Additions to Esther
Apocrypha II: Songs of the Three Young Men + Susanna + Bel & the Dragon / Esdras
Major Genres of NT Extracanonical Literature
Apocryphal Epistles: 3 Corinthians
Apocryphal Gospels I: Gospel of Judas
Apocryphal Gospels II: Gospel of Mary or others
Apocryphal Infancy Gospels: Protoevangelium of James / Gospel of Pseudo-Matthew
Apocryphal Acts I: Acts of Peter
Apocryphal Acts II: Acts of Paul & Thecla
Apocryphal Apocalyptic Literature I: Apocalypse of Peter
Apocryphal Apocalyptic Literature II: Apocalypse of Paul

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Hebrew Bible Exegesis
courses.description: This course continues from the basics of Biblical Hebrew I and II. It introduces the technical skills and steps involved in the exegesis of the Hebrew Bible. Therefore, the student will be taught the foundation of exegesis, how to use and read BHS (Biblia Hebraica Stuttgartensia) and BHQ (Biblia Hebraica Quinta), including textual criticism. The student will also learn to do lexical studies, analyze syntax with the appropriate tools. Students will learn to apply these skills on a few texts of different genres: poetry: Ps 23; instruction: Prov 2; and others. Through these primary skills, the student will be guided how to exegete the texts and also explore possibilities of interpretations.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies; Hebrew I (THEO1213 or THEO3217 or THEO5301) and Hebrew II (THEO1214 or THEO3218 or THEO5302)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes:

(1) know how to use the reference tools needed to do Hebrew exegesis

(2) know how to use BHS and BHQ

(3) analyze syntax with a given Hebrew text

(4) know how to use Hebrew Grammar Books

(5) explain how to do textual criticism with a given Hebrew text

(6) apply exegetical guidelines to exegete a given Hebrew text

(7) recognize how syntax, textual criticism and traditions can affect the interpretation of texts

(8) know how to make use of concordances, lexicons, and dictionaries for Hebrew exegesis

(9) analyze and evaluate commentaries

Attitude Outcomes:

(1) develop an appreciation for the long history and tradition of the transmission of texts

(2) be confident in using appropriate tools for specific needs to interpreting texts

(3) be confident in reading and exegeting Biblical Hebrew texts

(4) inculcate respect for meticulous scholarship to interpret a text

3. Hebrew Grammar and Syntax

4. Appreciating Commentaries

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Narrative Art in the Hebrew Bible
courses.description: Most parts of the Hebrew Bible is written in narrative form. In recent years, the literary approaches to the narrative in the Hebrew Bible are proliferating. The aim of this course is to explore the artistic and literary features of the narrative in Hebrew Bible. Students will learn how to appreciate the so-called poetics of the narrative in different parts of the Hebrew Bible, including the Pentateuch, the Former Prophets and the short stories of Jonah and Ruth, and acquire skills to analyze these narratives from a literary perspective. Furthermore, students will reflect on how the literary nature of the narrative in Hebrew Bible influences our view on Bible as History and Scripture.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity, MA in Christian Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
After this course, students should be able to

• recognize and describe different artistic features in the Biblical narrative

• appreciate the narrative art in the Hebrew Bible

• analyze the narrative in the Hebrew Bible from a literary perspective

• theorize the relationship between Biblical narrative, literature, history and theology

• reflect and design on the various use of Biblical narrative in different contexts

Week One: Course Introduction: Literary Studies of the Narratives in the Hebrew Bible

Week Two: Course Introduction: Literary Studies of the Narratives in the Hebrew Bible

Week Three: Narrativity: Plot

Week Four: Narrativity: Characters

Week Ten: Narrative and Narration: Contrast and Irony

Week Eleven: Narrative Cycle: Elijah and Ahab

Week Twelve: Narrator and Narration: Structure?

Week Thirteen: Conclusive Discussion: The Literary Studies of Hebrew Scripture

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Deuteronomistic History
courses.description: This course covers the major scholarship pertaining to the so-called Deuteronomistic History (DH), a perceived coherent literary unit that encompasses the books of Deuteronomy, Joshua, Judges, Samuel and Kings. It provides an overview of the major models on the literary production of the DH as put forth by the historical-critical scholars throughout the 19th to 21st century and examines the literary structure, central themes, and textual issues of these books by positing them within the literary culture of the ancient times. It traces the development of the current debates on the DH that both challenge various suppositions in the original formulation of the theory and yet continue to assert the validity of the overall thesis.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
• Describe and compare the original and various modified theories of the DH
• Appreciate the contributions that the historical critics have made to elucidate the relations between Deuteronomy and the Former Prophets.
• Deepen their awareness of the intellectual milieu in which this scholarly construct has originated and problematize the anachronistic elements of the original thesis
• Demonstrate a familiarity of the current approaches to the reading of the DH
courses.course_syllabus:
Modules:
Module 1: Introduction to the Original Thesis of the Deuteronomistic History (Weeks 1-2)
A. What is the Deuteronomistic History
B. Noth's Original Thesis
C. The Critiques of Noth's Original Thesis

Module 2: Two Major Modified Theory (Weeks 3-4)
A. A Modified Theory of the Crossian School; A Critique of the Two-Redaction Theory; A Critique on the So-Called Law Book and Josianic Reform
B. A Modified Theory of the Göttingen School; A Critique of the Three-Redaction Theory

Module 3: Revisiting the Definition of Deuteronomistic History (Weeks 5-6)
A. THe Issue of Pan-Deuteronomism
B. What Qualifies as "Deuteronomistic"?
C. What was/were the Deuteronomist(s)?

Module 4: The Idea of Deuteronomistic HIstoriography and Other Theories (Weeks 7-8)
A. DH in Relations to Ancient Eastern Historiography and Greek Historiography
B. Wolff's Kerygma of the Deuteronomistic History
C. Von Rad's Davidic Promise and Hope

Module 5: Individual Books in the Deuteronomistic History (Weeks 9-13)
A. The Book of Deuteronomy: Deuteronomism, Deuteronomy and Ancient Vassal Treaties, Deuteronomy as Constitution
B. The Book of Joshua: Inheriting the Promised Land, Conquest and Violence
C. The Book of Judges: Judges Cycle
D. The Book of Samuels and Kings: Deuteronomist's View of Monarchy

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Christianity in Chinese Literature
courses.description: This course adopts an innovative approach to examine the interactions between Christianity and Chinese literature from the 19th to early 20th centuries. Literary texts to be analyzed include mainly the late Qing missionary novels, and works of May Fourth writers (such as Lu Xun, Bing Xin and Xu Dishan). This course aims to widen the students' perspectives in the indigenization of Christianity in Chinese religious and literary contexts, the rhetorical influences of the Bible on the emergence of modern Chinese literature, and the interdisciplinary study of literature and religion.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Protestantism in Reform China
courses.description: The aim of this course is to help students to understand the development of Protestant Christianity in the Reform era in China, with emphasis on the interactions between Christianity and political, social and intellectual changes in China. Topics include church-state relationships, the Three-self Patriotic Movement, denominational and theological reflections, etc.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity, MA in Theological Studies, MA in Christian Studies, MA in Religious Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students are expected to
1. Demonstrate their knowledge of the course of the evolution of Chinese society during the Reform era and its impact on the development of Christianity during this period.
2. Hold deeper understanding and critical reflection towards various issues of Protestantism during the Reform era in China.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. 改革開放與中國基督教：變與常
2. 獨立自主：中國基督教與普世教會的聯繫
3. 三自與後三自：「愛國」教會的改革與困境
4. 家庭教會的「合法化」問題
5. 「宗派後」的宗派及教制問題
6. 城與鄉：基督教與中國社會〔3 月 10 日，袁浩博士〕
7. 中國基督教與公民社會
8. 接班人：中國神學教育的重建
9. 「相適應」到「中國化」：社會主義處境下的中國神學
10. 「新時代」下的中國基督教
11. 關懷中國教會：香港教會的中國情結與事工
12. 電影：「在期待之中」（甘小二）〔日期：3 月 3 日課堂〕
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Studies in Hong Kong Christianity
courses.description: This course examines the significant changes of Hong Kong society and its impacts on the development of Christianity since 1950s. Emphasis will be placed on social movement, political changes, 1997 issues, educational reform, as well as cultural and intellectual transformation. This course also explores the theological responses of Christian churches to the above challenges.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity, MA Theological Studies or MA Christian Studies
courses.learning_outcomes: By the end of the course, students are expected to demonstrate their knowledge of the basic historical evolution of Christianity in Hong Kong. Additionally, they shall be able to reflect, from both historiographical and theological perspectives, on the interactions between Christian churches and socio-political context in Hong Kong, as well as on the role which Christianity has played in cultural and intellectual transformation in Hong Kong. Furthermore, students are also expected to show their abilities to carry out independent research on the history and status quo of local churches.
courses.course_syllabus:
* *1. Introduction:** A Macro-history of Christianity in Hong Kong

* *2. Founding and Pioneering:** The Initiation of Hong Kong Christianity (1841 - 1860)

* *3. South China and Hong Kong:** Development and Self-governance (1860 - 1936)

* *4. Immigrants and Gospel (1937 - 1960s)**

* *5. The Formation of Localized Churches (1970s - )**

* *6. Mission and Education:** A History of Church-run Schools in Hong Kong

* *7. Heaven and Society:** Christianity and Social Engagement

* *8. God and Caesar:** Church-State Relations in Hong Kong

* *9. Gospel and Culture:** A Fusion of the West, East, and Local
courses.feedback_evaluation: Two course evaluations will be conducted. The first will be done midway through the course which is tailored to facilitate better progress through the course. The second will be conducted by the university wide exercise.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Christianity in the Chinese Diaspora
courses.description: This course examines the development of Christianity in Chinese Diaspora. Emphasis would be laid on the cases in Hong Kong, Taiwan, Macao, Southeast Asia and North America. Students shall examine and reflect on the trends of globalization and localization by comparing the experiences in various contexts.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
courses.learning_outcomes: Students are expected to recognize the basic knowledge of the theories of Diasporas, and to state the ingredients which help to explain the unique diasporas phenomenon and the experience of the assigned cases during 1920-1980s. Students shall be able to distinguish differences of various diasporas experiences of Chinese Christians, and to analyse and compare those experiences. By the end of the course, students are expected to demonstrate their abilities of forging their own understanding towards the relationship between diasporas and Chinese Christians, reflecting on the feasibility of diaspora theories and re-theorizing them in their own research.

1. Introduction
2. Diaspora & Chinese Christians
3. Case study : Xie fu-ya
4. Case Study: Xu, song-shi
5. Case Study: Christian Communities in South East Asia
6. Case Study: Christian Communities in North America
7. Conclusion

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: God,Creation,and Eschatology
courses.description: Since God in Christian understanding is self-revealed, the knowledge of God is not just about a language game. Through and in Jesus Christ, we come to know God as Trinity and Creator in terms of alpha and omega. This course attempts to provide a biblical, historical, theological, philosophical and contextual analysis of the doctrine of God.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To review critically the concepts of God, creation and eschatology from a historical-theological approach.
2. To correlate the doctrines of God, creation and eschatology to other Christian doctrines.
3. To apply the knowledge and skill developed in the course creatively to Christian liturgical and ethical life.
4. To make formal presentation on the theme of the doctrine of God, creation and eschatology to the Christian communities

- Apply the significance of those doctrines on the practical, social and political context

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Theology and Feminism
courses.description: The absence of women’s experiences and voices often seems the result and perpetuation of a blindness to gender inequality within the Church. To change this reality, we must return to a basic question: What does Christian theology reveal to the Church about the nature and place of women? The course aims at exposing students to a broad perspective and discussion about the dynamic relationship between theology and feminism. In addition to introducing the experiences of contemporary women and feminist critiques on violence, family, sexuality, poverty, ecology and media, the students will be encouraged to reexamine the ways in which the Western Judeo-Christian religious tradition has profoundly influenced our understanding of God and gender and to study the feminist interpretations of God-talks, sin and redemption, spirituality, leadership and church.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity, MA in Theological Studies, MA in Christian Studies, MA in Religious Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Delineate the historical oppression of the female gender in Church History and the Judeo-Christian traditions.
2. Review and describe the theological history of women’s identity, status and role in the family, church and society at large.
3. Analyze and criticize how theologies are formulated against the female gender in Christian history until today. Evaluate how formulations of the God-talk and other aspects of theology are also influenced by such theologies. Comment and specify the abuse, violence, subversion and impoverishment of the female gender and their relation to ecology.
4. Research and reconstruct female presence in history and Christian sources.
5. Describe and explain what constitutes gender, sexuality, and female embodiment, and draw implications on these discourses in the academia.
6. Construct practical frameworks to educate and raise awareness of the oppression, and also propose ideas how to promote a just and righteous community of faith and society.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Hermeneutics and Theology
courses.description: This course will examine the impact of contemporary hermeneutical theories on the doing of theology. A survey of the development from classical to modern and contemporary hermeneutics will be given. The influence of hermeneutical theories upon theological method, the rethinking of the nature of theology, the interpretation of bible, the explication of some theological categories, will be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity, MA in Theological Studies, MA in Religious Studies
courses.learning_outcomes: The students will be able to understand original works in the area of modern hermeneutics and related theological discourses, to appreciate the value of these works, and to develop a critical perspective to interpret other types of theology.
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I: Introduction and History
1. The Idea of Hermeneutics
2. Early Scriptural Hermeneutics
3. From Medieval to Reformation
4. The Beginning of Modern Hermeneutics

Part II: Selected Readings
5. Dasein analytic and its Christian overtune
6. Demythologization as existential interpretation
7. The transmission of kerygma in history
8. Pre-understanding and history of effect
9. Human finitude and universal history
10. Language and hermeneutics
11. Classic andtheology
12. Text and life
