courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Modernity and Theology
courses.description: This course examines the relation and interaction between modernity and theology, with particular focus on the challenges of modernity to Christian theology as well as the diverse theological responses to modernity in various historical and cultural contexts. Related issues, such as the contested interpretations of modernity, claims about the theological roots of Western modernity, and the prospect of constructive theology in global modernity, will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, the student is expected (a) to have an overview of the relation and interaction between modernity and theology; (b) to be able to understand and critically appreciate some important thinkers in relation to their contexts; (c) to be able to analyze the challenges of modernity in different realms and to evaluate the responses from Christian theology.
courses.course_syllabus:
I. Introduction & overview
1. “Modern”, “modernity”, “modernization”… and their relations to theology?
2. “Common” features of modernity as commonly articulated

II. Examinations from the historical perspective
3. Back to the medieval period: nominalism as the origin of modernity?
4. Protestant Reformation: a genuine watershed between ancient and modern?
5. The Enlightenment: what are the “new” things? And the religious dimension

III. Different features and theological responses
6. Tolerance: the establishment of a secular state and political theology
7. This-worldly: the rise of capitalism and the decline of the sacred
8. Science: the turn to this natural world and reason in place of revelation
9. Autonomy: self-assertion and the reoocupation of the sacred realm
10. Individualism: the change of aesthetics and the difficulty of consensus
11. Progress: a replacement or reminiscence of ancient apocalyptic vision

IV. Postscript instead of conclusion
12. Modernity – a project to be perfected or is collapsed? And the theological response?
13. “Post”-modern [theology]?! A failure announcement or a nostalgic symptom?

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Theological Systems and Methods
courses.description: This course examines and evaluates selected works of modern systematic theologians, such as Friedrich Schleiermacher, Karl Barth, Paul Tillich, Wolfhart Pannenberg, and Gordon Kaufman. It will investigate the structure and content of each theological system as well as the method used in constructing it. Special attention will be paid to the interdependence of method and system. While the course focuses on modern and contemporary theology, it will briefly survey a few classical examples of systematic theology, such as the works of John of Damascus, Thomas Aquinas, and John Calvin.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Describe and explain the basic concept of the systematic character and the different methodology of Christian faith and theology
2. Explain the historical context, doctrinal meaning and the significance of the different selected Christian theologians in concerning their theological construction
3. Reflect the interrelationship of the systematic and methodological consideration with other academic disciplines (different sciences)
4. Reflect the implication of the theological system and method in the modern and post-modern contexts.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Political and Liberation Theologies
courses.description: Both political and liberation theologies attempt to provide a theological reflection of the interaction between the Christian faith and the socio-political order, with reference to their particular context. They keep an active and critical dialogue with contemporary social theories. Issues like church-state relation, Christianity and human rights, Christianity and economic justice are their concern. The course not only introduces the historical development and the theological significance of political and liberation theologies, but also explores to construct a political and liberation theology that is relevant to the contemporary context.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To review critically the different concerns, contents and methodologies of political and liberation theologies.
2. To be engaged into a fruitful dialogue between political and liberation theologies and social theories.
3. To extend the knowledge and skill developed in the course for constructing a contextual political and liberation theology creatively.
4. To make formal presentation on the theme of political and liberation theologies to the Christian communities.
courses.course_syllabus:
1) Politics and theology
2) Liberation theologies
3) Public and Private
4) Political Theology in different contexts: Taiwan experiences
5) Social imaginary and Christian symbols
6) Hidden transcripts and power of the powerlessness
7) Transitional justice
8) Feminist Political Theology
9) Memory, identity and justice
10) Social action and civil society
11) Common good, human development and human rights
12) Power and government
13) Spirituality and politics
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Chinese Christian Thinkers
courses.description: This course is an in-depth study of the theological perspectives of several Christian thinkers in modern and contemporary China. Case studies include T.C. Chao, Watchman Nee, Y.T Wu, Wang Mingdao, K. H. Ting, etc. Special reference shall be made on the distinctive characteristics of their theological concerns, as well as their impact on Chinese Protestantism. Their contributions on Christianity indigenization and contextualization shall also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students are expected to
1. Understand the basic ideas held by the selected Christian thinkers.
2. Be able to analyse, discuss and evaluate the evolution and characteristics of Protestant theological thoughts in China.
3. Demonstrate their abilities to critically reflect on and evaluate the application of the theological perspectives in China by those thinkers.
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Cinema and Theology
courses.description: This course considers the various religious and theological dimensions of contemporary cinema, and examines a range of approaches to such endeavours. Since the inception of motion picture in 1895, cinema and institutional religions (including Christianity) have always been interested in each other – numerous films have used religious themes and motifs as subject matters, while religious communities have been eager to harness the cinema by critiquing, censoring, or making use of films in their ministries. The study of film from serious academic theological perspectives, however, was scarce until the mid 1990s. In this course, we explore a number of approaches by which the theological study of film can take place. These include, for example, the study of explicit representation of religious materials, the 'uncovering' of implicit religious motifs, the use of film as resource for theological reflection and construction. In particular, we shall consider how cinematic representations of certain important theological motifs may enrich conventional religious understanding. Films to be viewed and discussed cover a broad range from European art-house classics, popular Hollywood productions, to contemporary East Asian and Chinese language films.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Congregational Studies
courses.description: This course will familiarize students with the recent discourse of congregational studies flourished both in the US and the UK context. Students will be helped to see the significant impact that this discourse has on recent congregational life. Interdisciplinary research methods for understanding the identity, dynamics, and context of a congregation will be introduced. Students will also be equipped with some tools for analyzing the local congregations.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Christian Mission and Glocalization
courses.description: God’s mission (Missio Dei) is the fundamental of mission, and should be understood in context. The history of the Christian mission reveals that its mission is like an ‘Empire’ as well as a servant of the gospel. Apart from a critical review of the theology and practice of Christian mission, the course is to analyze the characteristics of glocalization and its implications for the understanding and practice of Christian mission.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To evaluate critically the history, practice and theology of mission.
2. To analyze and review how glocalization has affected Christian mission, with reference to different social contexts.
3. To apply the knowledge and skill developed in the course creatively to design, arrange and evaluate mission activities.
4. To make formal presentation on the theme of Christian mission to the Christian communities.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: History, Practice, and Theology of Christian Worship
courses.description: The course is designed to provide students with an in depth study of Christian Worship from Biblical, historical, liturgical, theological and contextual perspectives. After laying the foundation for liturgical and theological discussions from Biblical and historical angles, much emphasis will be placed on the development of worship forms from Vatican II to the recent ecumenical and post denominational liturgical revivals that reflect dynamic contemporary cultural and theological dialogues in the post modern era.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity, MA in Theological Studies, MA in Christian Studies, MA in Religious Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge outcome:
The students should have a solid historical sketch of the development of various traditions of Christian worship.
Attitude outcome:
The students may cultivate an ecumenical mind and become more appreciative of other traditions different from their own.
Skill outcome:
The students are able to make use other traditions to enhance their own in the evaluation and conduct of Christian worship.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Christian Worship and The Spirit of Liturgy
2. Biblical Basis of Christian Worship: Worship in Truth and Spirit (John 4: 19-24);Worship As Dialogue (Isaiah 6: 1-8); Design and Discharge of Worship (1 Corinthians 14).
3. The Language of Time: Church Calendar and Lectionary of the Christian Year.
4. Daily Office; Composition of Corporate Prayers.
5. The Language of Space: The Function of Liturgical Space; History of Liturgical Architecture; Liturgical Art
6. Symbols and Rituals in Christian Worship.
7. The Liturgy of the Primitive Church vis-à-vis Gnosticism and Paganism
8. The Sacraments and Christian Initiation
9. The Eucharist: The Shape and Theology of the West and the East Rites.
10. Reformation and Liturgical Reforms: The Normative Principle and Regulative Principle; The Anglican, Lutheran and Reformed Traditions; The Non-conformists: Quakers, Free Church, and Charismatic.
11. Liturgical Renewal of Vatican II and Ecumenical Movement
12. Sacred Music and Worship

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Twenty-First Century Hymnology
courses.description: This course aims at the study of hymns and the development of church music in historical perspectives. It will investigate how hymns, as carriers and interpreters of 2000 years of Christian faith, have laid their biblical foundation, and have incorporated historical and cultural elements as well as their respective musical styles to enrich the liturgy and shape our spirituality. It will also examine how the hymn explosion of the latter part of 20th century has opened up a new world of 21st century hymnology, which on the one hand has incorporated new vocabularies to deal with issues of human rights, social, economical and political justice, ecology and integrity of creation, and on the other hand has adapted musical languages of the modern world with diversified ethnic styles that has formed a new world of 21st century global hymns. Emphasis will be placed on the analysis and application of contemporary hymns and praise choruses musically, theologically and liturgically.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of this course, students are able to:
1. Be familiar with and evaluate the historical and theological development of congregational songs.
2. Demonstrate a critical and scholarly informed perspective on issues regarding congregational songs of the 21st century.
3. Select congregational songs with theological and liturgical discernment.
courses.course_syllabus:
I. Introduction to Congregational song and church music
II. Characteristics and Function of Congregational song
III. Historical Development of Congregational song
1. Biblical Times
2. Early Church

4. Reformation
5. British and American Hymns
IV. Movement and Issues in Congregational Song
1. Contemporary Hymns
2. Praise and Worship movement (Worldwide and in Korea)
3. Hymnology of China
4. Taize songs

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Models of Practical Theology
courses.description: This course aims at familiarizing the students with the practical theology movement in the past several decades. It will examine the practical nature of all theologies, and will introduce several models of practical theology. It also aims at helping students to see how the theological theories that they learn through lectures and readings may have bearings on their Christian lives and ministries.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Theological Studies
courses.course_syllabus:
What is Practical Theology?
- Nature of Theology—Theoretical or Practical or “theoretical vs. practical”?
- Duns Scotus and the debate over the nature of Theology in the Thirteenth/Fourteenth Century
- Practical Theology as a discipline—historical development
- Types/ Models/ Paradigms of Practical Theology
- On Practical Theology in Chinese Speaking Societies
- Methods and methodologies of Practical Theology
- --Empirical (qualitative inquiry) approach
- ----the approaches widespread in the British circles
- ----Illustrations
- -------A research on Protestant Death rites
- -------Spiritual Care in multifaith settings
- --Practical Theology as Action Research
- --Hermeneutical Approach
- ----theory and practice, application
- ----What is “Practical”/”Practice”?
- ----“Application” and Understanding: the Fundamental Hermeneutic Problem
- ----Illustration: Wesleyan reflection on Pathological Gambling
- --Stephen Pattison’s Practical Theology as “Critical Conversation”
- --Practical Theology as Critical Social Theory
- ----Illustrations:
- -------Lutheran reflection on local Higher Education in the context of Economic Globalization
- -------Church Growth discourse (HK)
- -------WHO spirituality vs. Asian Spirituality
- ----Class Experiment: *enjo kosai*

Some Domains (examples) of Practical Theology:
- Theological Education
- Theological Reflection
- --Models of theological reflection
- --Disjuncture and theological reflection
- --Learning style and theological reflection
- ----Reflection via integrative seminar

Integrative Seminar x 4:
- Students’ presentation (no audit [except special students] is allowed)
- by random assignment: 8 presenters + 8 reflection partners (2, 2, 2, 2)
- Each reflection partner group consists of two students who will engage in pre-session reflection with the two presenters separately.

courses.title: Sex, Marriage and Family
courses.description: This course aims at familiarizing the students with a practical theological approach to issues in connection with sex, marriage, and family. The contents cover the changing conceptions of sex, marriage, and families in the course of history, as well as the Christian traditions that give shape to the conceptions. Debates on the related issues and the theologies underneath will also be discussed. Besides, some related Christian counseling approaches will also be included in the course contents.

courses.title: The Reformation Era
courses.description: The 16th century brought a profound paradigm shift in the development of Christianity that has fundamentally changed church, society, and culture in the West. This change has had a global impact and played a crucial role in the process of modernization. The course introduces the students to the developments in church, theology, and society in 16th century Europe with a particular emphasis on the deep theological changes, particularly those connected to Luther, Calvin, and the Radical Reformation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
• Students shall be able to systematically and coherently understand different aspects of the transformations happening during this period: theological, spiritual, historical, social, political, and others.
• Students will extend their knowledge to how shifts in theological thinking affected the traditional configuration of society, state, culture, and religion
• The students will develop skills to make appropriate judgments about different perspectives on church history and issues that are still debated.
• The students will develop sensitivity regarding the diversity of Christian faith expressions.
• The students will learn to apply theological concepts based on the theoretical paradigms of the Reformation to assess controversial issues of the present.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Political, social, and cultural context of the late medieval time
• Medieval theology as background to the theological debates of the Reformation
• Historical aspects of the main reformers Luther, Zwingli, and Calvin and of the Reformation in England
• Systematic theological aspects of Reformation thought: o Soteriology
o Sacraments
o Ecclesiology
o Political theology
• Historical aspects of the post-Reformation period
• Reforms in Roman Catholicism
• Ecclesial, cultural, social, and political impacts of the Reformation

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Modern Western Christianity
courses.description: The purpose of the course is to introduce the students to the historical and theological developments in the Western Church from the Peace of Westphalia through Enlightenment, the history of awakenings and the renewals in the 20th century to the present. This course includes both developments of the church in Europe and North America, as they are closely linked.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
• The students will extend their knowledge of theological and ecclesial developments during the period.
• The students will be able to critically evaluate how, during the studied period, religious institutions influenced socio‐political developments and vice versa.
• The students will develop skills to make appropriate judgments about different perspectives on church history and issues that are still debated.
• The students will develop sensitivity regarding the diversity of Christian faith expressions and gain historical depth in their theological reflection.
• The critical study of church history helps the students to recover the voices of those who have been condemned as heresy.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Review: The Church during the Reformation Era; Introduction: What Moves Church History? The Church at the Beginning of Modernity
2. The Roman-Catholic Church during the 17th and 18th Centuries: Tradition and Revivalism
3. Faith vs Reason: The Church during the Period of Enlightenment I
4. Faith vs Reason: The Church during the Period of Enlightenment II
5. Church and Politics: Puritanism; Spiritual Movements in 17th and 18th Century Protestantism: Pietism and Methodism
6. Protestant Revival in the 18th and 19th Centuries: The First and Second Great Awakening
7. Revivalism in the 19th and 20th Centuries: Holiness Movement, Divine Healing and the Rise of Modern Pentecostalism and Charismatic Christianity
8. Tradition and Modernity: Roman Catholicism in the 19th and 20th Centuries
9. Protestantism in the 19th and 20th Centuries: Responding to Social Issues
10. The Church and Totalitarian Ideologies: Protestantism during the Wartime (Film-Watching)
11. Renewal in the 20th Century: Ecumenism and Evangelicalism
12. Christianity as A World Religion

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Biblical Hebrew I
courses.description: This course, and the sequel Biblical Hebrew II in the next semester, are designed to enable students to read Biblical Hebrew. In this course, Biblical Hebrew I, students learn the alphabets to the basic forms of Hebrew sentences. Students not only learn how to read simple sentences from the Hebrew bible, but also learn to identify different parts of speech, and basic grammar. Students will also learn some Hebrew songs which accompany the lessons. This course follows closely to its textbook, Learn Biblical Hebrew by John H. Dobson (2005). Biblical Hebrew I will cover Lessons 1-13.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity and MA in Theological Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes
(1) recite and write down from memory the Hebrew alphabets, vowels and their transliterations
(2) pronounce and read Hebrew words
(3) recite from memory Genesis 1:1 (D 2.4; p. 18); Deuteronomy 6:4-5 (D 5.6; p. 55); the songs: We welcome you (D 1.13 Q5; p. 16) and Blessed are You (D 5.9 Q6; p. 58)
(4) memorize at least 350 Hebrew words perfectly by the end of the course
(5) recognize words and identify them correctly as nouns, verbs, prepositions, constructs, suffixes, adjectives, infinitives or participles
(6) identify the forms of questions, commands and requests
(7) parse a given word
(8) explain the usage of adjectives, participles, infinitives, prefix and suffix conjugations, waw consecutive conjugation as well as concepts of perfective and non-perfective
(9) deduce the functions of each component after parsing a given sentence
(10) identify basic grammar implications in simple Hebrew sentences or phrases

Attitude Outcomes
(1) develop an interest and respect for the historical and cultural development of the Hebrew language from its paleo-Hebrew script until its Aramaic script, and the modern Hebrew language
(2) appreciate the distinctiveness of the Biblical Hebrew language
(3) cultivate an interest to read Biblical Hebrew texts
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The Hebrew Alphabets and Vowels
2. Word Order in Sentences
3. The Pronominal Suffixes and Pronouns
4. The Narrative and Completed Action
5. Parsing
6. The Adjectives
7. Absolute and Construct Nouns
8. The Continuing Action
9. The Previous and Future Action
10. Possession and Question Tags
11. Commands and Requests
12. Infinitives
13. Numbers

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Biblical Hebrew II
courses.description: This course, a sequel to Biblical Hebrew I, will continue to follow the textbook, Learn Biblical Hebrew by John H. Dobson (2005), covering Lessons 12–25. It will cover all the binyanim of Hebrew as well as understanding concepts of Hebrew syntax, function of prepositions and the principles of translating narratives and poetry and attempt a few exercises. In particular, we shall read the Masoretic text of the book of Jonah (a narrative with a poem) with the help of the Lexicons/Dictionaries and other Bible aids.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in Master of Divinity and MA in Theological Studies
Pre-requisite: Hebrew I (THEO1213 or THEO3217 or THEO5301)
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes

The students will be competent in the following abilities:

(a) recognize every component in the parts of speech learned in THEO5301

(b) identify the binyanim and functions of all verbs

(c) recall the forms and functions of the prepositions and particles

(d) identify, recognize at least 500 of the most common Biblical Hebrew words found in the Hebrew Bible

(e) search words in the Biblical Hebrew dictionaries and lexicons and explain the entries, in particular the BDB Lexicon.

(f) parse and translate given phrases/sentences and the book of Jonah

(g) use the parsing tools of Bible Works 10

(h) read and translate short narrative passages and some poems from the Hebrew Bible

(i) read and explain the grammar in the book of Jonah

Attitude Outcomes

The students will:

(a) be confident to read a Biblical Hebrew passage on their own with the necessary tools

(b) develop the habit of reading Biblical Hebrew passages

(c) appreciate the basic tasks to do exegesis and interpretation

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: New Testament Greek I
courses.description: This course provides students with an introduction to the basic grammar and vocabulary of New Testament Greek, in order to enable students to read the original New Testament texts.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity and MA in Theological Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes:
On the successful completion of this unit, students should be able to:
1. master the basic syntax and a working vocabulary of New Testament Greek; and
2. read and translate simple Greek texts

Attitude Outcomes:
Throughout the learning process, students are expected to:
1. develop a regular revision practice;
2. develop a positive attitude to face difficulties in learning; and
3. develop an initiative to help others and seek help from others by means of group study.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Pronunciation of Greek words:
- Sound and rules of pronunciation of alphabet
- Rules on accent and syllables
2. Bible Reading and Analysis
- Listening and reading Matthew 6 and John 1
3. Noun
- Concept of declension; first and second declension
- Pronouns: personal and demonstrative pronouns
- Basic modifier of noun
4. Greek Verb System
- Concept of inflection, mood, tense, aspect and voice
- Present and future indicative
- Imperfect and aorist active indicative
5. Preposition
- Basic rules on the use of most commonly used prepositions

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Introduction to the Hebrew Bible
courses.description: This course orientates students to the diverse scholarship which encompasses the study of the Hebrew Scripture: from archaeology, historical-critical, grammatico-historical, socio-historical methodologies to the history of composition of the biblical books, languages, religions and literature of the period before the common era. Inevitably, it also introduces the world of the ancient Near East – its history, religions and literature, which the Hebrew Scripture belonged and related to. This course traces the challenges confronted bythe nation of Israel from its beginning up until the period of the Second Temple.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in Master of Divinity
Exclusion: THEO5919 The Hebrew Bible in Contexts
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes:
1. The students will know and understand
a. the general overview of the contents in the Hebrew Bible
b. the direct relationship of the composition of the books to her contexts
c. a general grasp of the scholarship pertaining to the study of the Hebrew Bible
2. The students can describe, explain and discuss
a. the main issues related to the composition and redaction of the books in the Hebrew Bible
b. the main issues of critical scholarship concerning the origin and identity of Israel
c. the proposed historical contexts of the Hebrew Bible
d. the relationships or/and tensions between the traditions underlying the theological motivations and the contemporary
e. situation/s of the text

Attitude Outcomes:
The students will appreciate
a. the making/compilation of the Hebrew Bible
b. the necessity for language acquisition in the study of the Hebrew Bible
c. the diverse research faculties in the study of the Hebrew Bible
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: Course Introduction; Introduction: Imaginative Remembering; Literature and Genre
2. Torah (1): Introduction to Torah Hebrew Bible as (Christian) Scripture
3. Torah (2): Genesis; Exodus 1-18 Myth, Legend and ANET/Archaeology
4. Torah (3): Exodus 25-40, Leviticus, Number 1-10; Cult and Priestly school
5. Torah (4): Exodus 19-24, Numbers 11-36, Deuteronomy; Law and Narrative
6. Prophets (1): Introduction to the Prophets, Joshua, Judges; History and Deuteronomistic History
7. Prophets (2): Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel; Literary Prophet and Their Social World
8. Prophets (3): 1 and 2 Samuel, 1 and 2 Kings; Narrative and Ideology
9. Prophets (4): Minor Prophets; Twelve prophet as a book
10. Writings (1): Introduction to the Writings, Psalms; The Canonical Study of the Psalms
11. Writings (2): Job, Proverbs; Wisdom Literature
12. Writings (3): Five Scrolls, Ezra-Nehemiah; Hebrew Bible and the early Judaism
13. Writings (4)/ Conclusion: Daniel, 1 and 2 Chronicles; Apocalyptic Literature and the Rewritten Bible; Concluding Reflection: Hiddenness of God

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Introduction to the New Testament
courses.description: The main purpose of this course is to give students a general understanding the text of the New Testament, its methods of studies, its background and the issues involved. To achieve this purpose, it is necessary for students to know how the NT is interpreted in the light of modern thoughts. This involves firstly a good knowledge of the meaning of the basic text of the NT - this is in fact the prerequisite condition for students who are going to take this course; those do not know the text of the NT have to read through it twice (both students who are going to take this course; those do not know the text of the NT have to read through it twice (both Chinese and English version) at least. Besides, students are also required to read some basic works of modern interpretation of the NT.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
For students in Master of Divinity
Exclusion THEO5910 New Testament in Contexts
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes:
1. To give students a general understanding the text of the New Testament, its methods of studies, its background and the issues involved; and
2. To be able to grasp the method of Bible study and exegesis, particularly Pauline Letters.
Skills Outcomes:
1. To enhance critical intelligence thinking; and
2. To enhance analytical ability throughout exegesis.
Attitude Outcomes
1. To develop one’s ability to have a critical and yet sympathetic understanding and appreciation of different church traditions and scholarly perspectives; and
2. To develop one’s sensitivity to the limit of doctrines and enhance openness to different exegesis.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. History of the New Testament
- Investigate the emergence of New Testament and how it became a cannon of Christianity.
2. Contexts of New Testament
- Investigate the social, political, economic, philosophical and literary context of New Testament and how they affect the development of the text.
3. New Testament Criticisms
- Investigate the basic ideas and methodology of major historical criticisms of New Testament
4. Interpretation of New Testament
- Basic interpretation method in interpreting New Testament in light of the contexts
5. Main theme of different books
- Introducing the basic thoughts of various books in New Testament

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Wisdom and the Psalms
courses.description: This course studies the “wisdom” genre of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament, namely Job, Proverbs, Ecclesiastes, Ecclesiasticus and the Wisdom of Solomon, and some wisdom passages in the prophetic genre, as well as the book of Psalms. It studies the concept of “wisdom” in these books, and their distinction from, and relation to the other books of the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament. At the same time, it also considers its relationship to the ancient Near East genre of instruction literature.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes:
1. The students will know and understand
a. the historical background to the wisdom literature as genre in the Old Testament and the general scholarship
b. the rudimentary of Hebrew poetry
c. the general scholarship pertaining to scholarship in Psalms
2. The students can describe, explain and evaluate
a. the major literary features of wisdom books and the division in the Books of Psalms
b. the major themes, purposes and historical contexts and relevance of the individual books
c. the relationship between Psalms, the wisdom literature and the other genres and books of the Old Testament
d. the relevance of these books to the world today

Attitude Outcomes:
The students will appreciate:
a. the relevance of this genre to other cultures and their distinctions
b. the emotional and spiritual livelihood of Israel in relation to their deity as they confront political and societal challenges
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Course Introduction, What is Wisdom?
2. Overview on Wisdom Literature Scholarship, Wisdom Theology; Hebrew Poetry and Parallelism
3. .The Book of Proverbs (I)
4. The Book of Proverbs (II);
5. Qoheleth (I)
6. Qoheleth (II)
7. Job (I)
8. Job (II)
9. Introduction on Psalms
10. Psalms (I)
11. Psalms (II)
12. Psalms (III)
13. Concluding Discussion

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Synoptic Gospels
courses.description: This course comprises a study of the purpose and theology of the Synoptic Gospels (Matthew, Mark and Luke), comparing their distinct characteristics and looking at their similarities and differences. The course begins with a critical survey of the history of the Synoptic problem (how to explain the relationship between Matthew, Mark, and Luke) and proposed solutions. Exegesis of selected passages will be carried out to understand the original setting of individual gospel.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes:
1. To have basic knowledge of the content of the Synoptic Gospels;
2. To be sensitive to the similarities and differences of the Synoptic Gospels; and
3. To be able to grasp the method of Bible study and exegesis, particularly Synoptic Gospels.
Skills Outcomes:
1. To enhance critical intelligence thinking; and
2. To enhance analytical ability throughout exegesis.
Attitude Outcomes:
1. To develop one’s ability to have a critical and yet sympathetic understanding and appreciation of different church traditions and scholarly perspective; and
2. To develop one’s sensitivity to the limit of doctrines and enhance openness to different exegesis.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Johannine Literature
courses.description: This course will include a study of the authorship, purpose and main themes of the Johannine literature. Special attention will be given to some selected passages from the Gospel according to John, the Epistles of John and Revelation (Apocalypse).
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes:
1. To have basic knowledge of the content, theology and historical contexts of Johannine Literature (including Apocalypse);
2. To have basic knowledge of the so-called "Johannine Community";
3. To be able to understand particularly the Gospel of John (or the Apocalypse); and
4. To be able to grasp the method of Bible study and exegesis, particularly Johannine Literature.

Skills Outcomes:
1. To enhance critical intelligence thinking; and
2. To enhance analytical ability throughout exegesis.

Attitude Outcomes:
1. To develop one’s ability to have a critical and yet sympathetic understanding and appreciation of different church traditions and

2. To develop one’s sensitivity to the limit of doctrines and enhance openness to different exegesis.
courses.course_syllabus:
• Issues in Critical Studies of the Johannine Literature in the NT
• The Gospel of John (Literary Features, Christology, Social Historical Contexts, Jewish-Christian Hostility, Theological Views, Faith and Community, Resurrection and Mission)
• The Johannine Epistles (1 John: Tradition and Schism, 2 John: Leadership and Conflict, 3 John: Hospitality and Isolation)
• The Book of Revelation (Literary Genre and Visionary Rhetoric, Social Historical Contexts, Visions in Heaven, Visions on Earth, Visions of New Haven, New Earth and New City)
• Legacy of the Johannine Literature (Gnosticism, Community, Hope, How to Interpret it today)
courses.feedback_evaluation:
Students are encouraged to share their learning experience throughout the course.
Student’s weekly oral presentations of critical reviews and exegesis-research in class provide concrete and early feedback for the progress of the course and for the adjustment of its pedagogy before the course is finished.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Pauline Letters
courses.description: This course is a study of the Pauline and Deuteropauline Letters. Through comparing some of the critical passages from both categories, the course will explore the dating, authorship, purpose and the development of the Pauline theology.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes:
1. To have basic knowledge of the content, theology and historical context of Pauline Letters;
2. To have basic knowledge of historical Paul;
3. To be able to understand particularly the first letter of Pauline Letters (i.e. the Letter to the Romans); and
4. To be able to grasp the method of Bible study and exegesis, particularly Pauline Letters.

Skills Outcomes:
1. To enhance critical intelligence thinking; and
2. To enhance analytical ability throughout exegesis.

Attitude Outcomes:
1. To develop one’s ability to have a critical and yet sympathetic understanding and appreciation of different church traditions and scholarly perspectives; and
2. To develop one’s sensitivity to the limit of doctrines and enhance openness to different exegesis.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Course Introduction + Problems in interpreting Paul
2. Basic concept in interpreting Pauline letters
3. Interpretation history of Pauline letters
4. Context of Paul (1): 2nd temple Judaism and New Perspective of Paul
5. Context of Paul (2): Social World of Paul including the Political and Economic situation of Roman Empire
6. Core Pauline theological motif 1 - Theology
7. Core Pauline theological motif 2 – Eschatology
8. Core Pauline theological motif 3 - Christology
9. Core Pauline theological motif 4 - Love
10. Interpretation Method: Socio-rhetorical Interpretation 2
11. Letter to Philemon: Demonstration of SRI application
12. Conclusion

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Pentateuchal Studies
courses.description: This course covers the major scholarship pertaining to the books of Genesis, Exodus, Leviticus, Numbers and Deuteronomy. It not only examines the themes and historical purposes for these books, but also orientates the students to the complexities of the contents and purposes for these books as evidenced by the prominent scholarship throughout the 19th to the 21st century. It tracks the recent development of the debates pertaining to the source theories of J, E, D and P; and also recent alternative theories and methodologies to the study of the Pentateuch.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes:
The students will know and understand:
a. the general influence of the ancient Near East cultures on the composition of the Pentateuch
b. the scholarship on Pentateuch in relation to the composition, history, themes and methodologies of interpretations from 19th – 21st century
c. the source theories of J, E, D and P.
The students can describe, explain and discuss and evaluate
a. the themes and purposes of the Pentateuch
b. the historical and social contexts of the Pentateuch
c. the relationship of the Pentateuch to the rest of the Hebrew Bible
d. the contemporary scholarship emerging in Pentateuchal scholarship with regards to methodologies of interpretation
e. the current status of J, E, D and P.

Attitude Outcomes:
The students will appreciate:
a. the process of the composition, redaction and transmission of the Pentateuch
b. the significance of Pentateuch to the Jews and its continual influence on the three communities of faith: Judaism, Islam and Christianity

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Prophetic Literature
courses.description: This course covers selected readings from the second portion of the Hebrew bible, the Prophets, in particular the latter prophets, which includes Isaiah, Jeremiah, Ezekiel and the book of the Twelve (Minor Prophets). Historical studies aided with contextual interpretations will be the approach taken in engaging the biblical text, while theological and exegetical studies of the text will interact vigorously with contemporary social, political, economic and cultural dimensions of the public life. Insights and influences from modern literary and critical theories, social sciences and humanities, and various inter-disciplinary approaches will also be introduced and applied in the course of interpretation.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes:
(1) To be able to understand prophetic literature in terms of its historical scholarship and contemporary interpretations.
(2) To be able to engage the prophetic text with contemporary contextual issues.
Attitude Outcomes
(1) To develop students’ ability to have a critical and yet sympathetic understanding and appreciation of the prophetic literature of
the Hebrew bible within the milieu of modern biblical scholarship.
(2) To develop students’ sensitivity to the relevancy of biblical prophetic literature to the public dimension of human life.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. The social world of the Hebrew prophets: This section covers the role of a prophet and the nature of prophecy in ancient Southwest Asia and Israel in relation to the social issues of its time.
2. The historical context: The Hebrew prophets will be situated in their signifying contexts from the Neo-Assyrian empire to the Persian empire.
3. Major sections and Individual books: The structure and literary features of prophetic literature of different major sections (the Former Prophets, the Latter Prophets, and the Twelve) and individual books will be adumbrated.
4. Critical approaches: Recent scholarship in a variety of critical methods will be discussed.
5. Theological notions: Major theological notions include covenant, messianism, inviolability of Zion, theodicy, retributive logic, universalism, ḥesed, and restoration.
6. Critical issues: Critical issues include vaticinium ex eventu, the scheme of prophecy and fulfillment, social justice, the marital and sexual metaphor, divine violence, and historicity.
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: The book of Ezra-Nehemiah and the books of Chronicles
courses.description: This course focuses on the books of Ezra, Nehemiah and Chronicles in the Hebrew Bible, which are important parts of Hebrew Bible Historiography reflecting the situation of the Jews in the Second Temple Period. The scholarship associated with the Second Temple/Persian Period is also soaring in new and exciting frontier which we hope this course can help students to follow such a trend. Issues including textual criticism, authorship and readership, sources, theme and theology will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.course_syllabus:
Second Temple Period: To call the time when the post-exilic Israelites were ruled under the Persian empire Second Temple Period is to highlight the centrality of the rebuilt temple toward the development of the ideologies and theologies in that period. We will investigate why and how the Second Temple Period was a time when Jewish literary activities were most vibrant and the formative period that the early Judaism and Christianity’s main ideas emerged. The matter on how to call this important period in the Jewish history will be raised: Second Temple period is better than the term “intertestamental period” which traditionally regards as a time of silent in Divine revelation.

Persian colonization and Yehud province: In order to establish the historical and sociological context of the biblical books, the history of Persian empire and its colonization program will be introduced and discussed. Yehud as a province of Persian colonization and its significance in the Jewish self-understand and political make-up will be discussed.

Different Social Identities of the Jews: Exclusive and Inclusive Jewish Community: We will look into the different communities in the Second Temple Period, namely the diaspora in different region, the Golah in Babylonian soil, the returnee and “the people of the land”/local population. We will examine how these groups formulated and articulated their ideologies within the Hebrew Bible and their viewpoints on various issues, especially on these communities’ manner toward outsiders, either they were inclined toward an exclusive policy or a more inclusive one.

Aramaic Sections of the Hebrew Bible: Parts of the Hebrew Bible are written in Aramaic, the lingua franca in the Second Temple Period. We will study the Aramaic section within the book of Ezra and discuss the reason behind this diglossia phenomenon. As a result, we will learn how different scholars reconstruct the history behind these Aramaic texts within the Hebrew Bible.

Temple worship and Temple Personnel in the Persian Period: As a new temple were rebuilt during the Persian period, it resulted in a re-installment of temple worship in the Jewish life. The various topics regarding this theme, from the meaning of temple worship in before and after the exile to the change of importance and activities of different temple personnel in the post-exilic time, will be explored during the course.

Prophecy in the Second Temple period: Did prophecy cease during the Second Temple Period? How the old prophecies were interpreted during this time? This part of the course explore the interpretative activities regarding to the divine messages in the Second Temple Period.

The new understanding of Historiography and its ideology: The writing of a nation’s past can take many forms. We will discuss how the book of Ezra-Nehemiah as a Autobiographical Memoir and the book of Chronicle as a Utopia Literature contribute to the new understanding of historiography in the scholarly world.

Ezra-Nehemiah-Chronicles as Christian Scripture: Various themes relating to Christian theology such as Retribution, Restoration, Canonization and the Pastoral aspect of the biblical books concerning our course will be explored.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Early and Medieval Church
courses.description: The purpose of the course is to introduce the students to the historical and theological developments in the early and medieval church, from Jesus to the dawn of the Reformation and to engage them in a critical dialogue with earlier forms of contextualization of the Christian faith.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
a) The students will gain a general knowledge of the theological and ecclesial development during the covered period.
b) The students become familiar with key doctrinal development and the interplay between religious institutions and socio-political circumstances of the early and medieval period of the church.
c) The students will get acquainted with different perspectives on church history and with issues that are still debated.
d) The students will develop sensitivity regarding the diversity of Christian faith expressions and gain historical depth in their theological reflection.
e) The students learn about historical forms of contextualization.
f) The critical study of church history helps the students to recover the voices of those who have been condemned as heresy.
courses.course_syllabus:
Session 1:
Introduction to the course
The church in the first two centuries
• What is the Relation of Jesus to the Church?
• Steps in the Development of the Early Church and the spread of Christianity
• The Separation between the Church and the Jewish Community

Session 2: Christianity and politics
Conflicts with the State
The extension of Christianity in the first three centuries

Session 3: Challenges to the faith in the second century and the development of early Catholic theology
The pre-catholic church
Gnostic crisis, Marcionism and the Montanist crisis
Response to the challenges to the faith: Development of catholic theology

Session 4: Christianity and culture: The encounter with Hellenist philosophy
Hellenistic philosophies
Patristic theology
The early Trinitarian debates

Session 5: Christianity becoming the religion of the empire
The so-called Constantinian conversion
Religious policy after Constantine
Constantine’s impact on the religious life of the catholic church
Impact on the theology of the catholic church
Counter-movements to the imperial church: Ascetism and monasticism

Session 6: Theological and ecclesial controversies of the 4th century
Donatism
The Arian controversy until the Council of Nicea
The continuation of the controversy until Constantinople

Session 7: Theology and christological debates in the 5th century
The Council of Chalcedon
Augustine

Session 8: Mission history: the extension of Christianity and its inculturation in new contexts
The Encounter of the catholic church with non-Roman kingdoms
Shifts in world Christianity and the confrontation with Islam

Session 9: Church and state: The growth of papal and ecclesial power
The history of the papal claim of primacy
The development of the secular power of the popes
The conflict between the papacy and the Empire
Medieval papacy, church and state

Session 10: The history of a growing division: The churches in East and West on separate ways
Christological debates of the 6th and 7th century
The iconoclastic debate

Session 11: The history of the other church: Revivalism, reform, and alternative
Christian faith expression in medieval times
Christian mysticism
Monastic reform movements
Mendicant orders
Radical and heretical movements
The Catholic Church and the ‘other church’

Session 12: Outward militancy and inward divisions in high and late medieval times
The crusades
The inquisition
The Babylonian captivity of the church and the divided papacy
The conciliar church reform movement

Session 13: Theological Developments during the Medieval Time
Representatives, forms and historical development of medieval theology
The controversy about the universals
The controversy between rationalism and voluntarism

courses.description: This course aims at helping students to gain a comprehensive understanding on the history of Protestant Christianity in Hong Kong. The first section will emphasize on the historical development of Christianity in different stages. The second section will investigate the relationship and interaction between Christianity and Hong Kong society from topical perspectives.

Learning outcomes
(1) To assist students to understand the historical development of Christianity in Hong Kong.
(2) To assist students to acquaint the methods of conducting research on local church history
Attitude Outcomes

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: History of Christianity in China
courses.description: This course aims at giving the students a macro historical picture of Christianity in China from the seventh century to the present. Special attention will be paid to the interaction between Christianity and the Chinese society.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
Learning outcomes
(1) To assist students to understand the historical development of Christianity in China
(2) To assist students to acquaint the methods of conducting research on Chinese church history
Attitude Outcomes
(1) To develop and affirm students’ identity towards Chinese church history
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Voices from the Past1: Writing the History of Christianity in China
2. Experience: Empiricist Research on Christianity in Contemporary China
3. Preface: Traces of Early Christian Encounters
4. Friendship: Images of the Jesuits in Imperial China
5. The Task: The “Protestant Plan” for China
6. Sisters: Portraits of Women in Chinese Christianity
7. Culture: The Story of 19th-century Chinese Protestantism
8. Contextualization: In Search of an Indigenous Chinese Christianity
9. Conflict: Remembering the Anti-Christian Movement
10. Officials: Tracking Chinese Christianity vis-à-vis CCP rule
11. Perceptions: Histories of Contemporary Chinese Christianities
12. Student Presentations: proposals
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: History of Christianity in Asia
courses.description: The course introduces the students to the history of Christianity in Asia, from the first century and the mission to India through the Sassanid and the Mongolian period, the spread of Roman-Catholic and Protestant faith in the colonial era to the development of independent Christianity since the 20th century. A significant focus of the course will be on more recent developments in different parts of Asia.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
a) The students will gain an understanding of the historical development of Christianity in Asia and will learn to perceive and appreciate Christianity in Asia as a partly parallel and independent rather than as latter development to Christianity in Europe.
b) The students will learn about the contemporary challenges of Christian churches in different contexts of Asia and the reasons for different growth developments. They will learn to distinguish between joint Asian concerns and the concerns of particular contexts.
c) In the different historical developments of Christianity in Asia, the students will encounter different models of Christianity and Christian relations to their cultural environment. The students will equally discover different issues of contextualization.
d) The students will develop sensitivity regarding mission, ecumenism, and contextualization in the postcolonial Asian context and learn about different Christian responses to the multi-religious context of Asia. The focus on the diversity of Christian churches and faith expressions in Asia leads beyond the dualism of local church and church in the West and helps perceive Christianity in a multi-polar world.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1: Introduction to the course
Week 2: The spread of Christianity in the first 10 centuries
Week 3: Asian Christianity from 1000 to 1800
Week 4: The emergence of the Protestant mission movement
Week 5: Protestant Christianity across 19th century Asia
Week 6: Korean Christianity
Week 7: Christianity and Buddhism in Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia
Week 8: Christianity in Thailand
Week 9: Christianity in Myanmar
Week 10: Christianity facing Islam
Week 11: Christianity in India and Nepal
Week 12: Global faith movements in the Asian context
Week 13: Conclusions
courses.feedback_evaluation: End-of-term university wide course evaluation will be conducted in class

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Systematic Theology I
courses.description: Systematic theology can be understood as the theological discipline that constructively articulates the meaning, coherence, and implications of Christian beliefs. This course aims at providing students with a solid methodological foundation for the study of systematic theology by investigating various issues that belong to the “prolegomena” of systematic theology, including the formative factors of theology (such as revelation, Bible, tradition, experience, reason, and culture), theological language, and theological methods.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, the student is expected (a) to have an historical overview of the major paradigms in Christian theology; (b) to understand significant issues and diverse views regarding the formative factors of theology (especially the Bible, but also tradition, culture, theological language, etc.); (c) to have basic knowledge of exemplary theological systems and methods; (d) to be able to think analytically and critically in the field of theology.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Local Church Study
courses.description: This course aims at helping students to gain a comprehensive understanding on the history of the field of study namely congregational study. It also helps student to critically understand the theologies behind different models of church, and how these theologies of church are translated into practice in the practical world. Special attention will be paid to the Hong Kong church--its historical developoment, its theologies, its denominational traditions, polity and others. Students will have chance to analyse their own churches according to what they learn from class.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
知識方面：
從歷史角度初步了解本地新教之發展與現況
把握本地新教堂會的社會學及神學實況
學習分析影響著本地新教堂會發展之幾個因素
認識堂會研究之方法及方法論基礎
態度方面：
對堂會發展與現況持批判而開放的態度
更關心本地堂會發展
技巧方面：
能初步以堂會研究之方法去分析本地教會議題

堂會牧者所遇見之困難與權力分析

本地女牧者之體會

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Pastoral Theology
courses.description: This course covers three areas: 1) the historical and theological position of Pastoral Theology in Theological Studies and its uniqueness; 2) different types of Pastoral Theology and their aims; and 3) Ancient and contemporary church models and pastoral emphases.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
To understand what is Pastoral Theology with reflection from personal pastoral experience.
To construct Pastoral Theology from the Bible, church and Chinese cultural traditions.
To understand different emphases of Pastoral Theology from multiple perspectives and from histories of different denominations.
courses.course_syllabus:
Session 1: The Pastor as a Person (1)—Pastor’s Relationships: The Congregation, Collegiality, Denomination and the Society.
Session 2: The Pastoral Office-The Ordination of the Ministry of Word and Sacraments.
Session 3: The Local Church-An Institutional Organization and a Living Organism.
Session 4: The Pastor as the Priest
Session 5: The Pastor as the Celebrant; Administration of Holy Baptism and Holy Communion
Session 6: The Pastor as Preacher and Teacher;
Session 7: Preaching According to the Church Calendar and Planning of the Pulpit.
Session 8: The Pastor as a Person (2)--Pastor’s Capability: Gifts, Spirituality, Attitude and Mental Hygiene.
Session 9: The Pastor as Prophet
Session 10: The Pastor as Counselor
Session 11: The Pastor as Leader and Change Agent
Session 12: Pastoral Ethics
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Denominational Tradition and Polity
courses.description: The course is aimed at deepening the students’ understanding of the historical background, the theological basis and the church practice of one of the denominational traditions of the supporting churches of Divinity School of Chung Chi College. The critical reflection of the denominational tradition and polity equips the students to identify patterns of transformation and change in a denominational tradition and guide them in devising strategies for the continuous reform of tradition and polity.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
a) Knowledge about the history of the church tradition
b) Understanding of theological orientation
c) Familiarity and understanding of the specific liturgical practice
d) Acquaintance with the social and educational service and the missionary outreach.
e) Understanding of congregational growth patterns and ability to apply analytical tools for the analysis of growth patterns.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. 難以捉摸的衞斯理約翰（John Wesley)
2. 十六至十八世紀的英國宗教社會與政治狀況
3. 獻呈基督—衞斯理宗的宣教佈道（Prof.Jack.Jackson)
4. 十八世紀循道衞理宗福音復興運動歷史
5. 神學核心—救恩階梯（一）
6. 神學核心—救恩階梯（二）
7. 蒙恩途徑—問責任性的信仰群體
8. 個人與群體的生命禮儀—靈修、崇拜與聖禮（一）
9. 個人與群體的生命禮儀—靈修、崇拜與聖禮（二）
10. 牧職的源起與發展—遊行傳道、本地傳道、聖職制度
11. 窮人的福音—與窮苦者同行的社會關懷
12. 神學四柱及時代回應
13. 香港循道衞理會的發展與傳承
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.

Dr. LI Kwan Hung Leo,

courses.description:
This course will cover: 1) the principles, construction and technique in preaching; and
2) the content and message of a sermon in contemporary world. This course will include video-taping students’ preaching. Tutorials after preaching will be conducted for the improvement of technique and content.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
To understand the principle of preaching on theological topics.
To understand the integration of different types of preaching and the way of preparation.
To learn and practice the techniques and styles in delivering a sermon.
courses.course_syllabus:
(一) 課程評估
分享／引論
聽道／講道經驗及心得
何謂講道學（Homiletics）？
講道的構成因素——真道、表達、使命、講者、聽眾、技巧、權柄

何謂道？
聖經與道
宣講與教導之不同
道與行
(三) 講章的分類
專題式講道
經文式講道
釋經講道
(四) 講章的性質
佈道
培靈
奮興
牧養
婚禮
喪追思
紀念日
聖曆及特別主日
(五) 經文的選擇與運用
用一段經文的好處
選擇經文要留意的地方
如何運用經文
(六) 如何決定主旨
主旨的必要
主旨的選擇
(七) 如何決定題目
(八) 講章的結構
分段與大綱
引論、本論、結論
(九) 導言
三個目的
(十) 例證
講道的天窗
(十一) 結論與應用
應用的重要性
應用的三個成份

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Liturgics
courses.description: The course aims at equipping students with the understanding of the history and theology of the sacred worship, which include the development of the sacred worship, the notion of liturgical time, of ecclesiastical year, of sacred space, of Monastic and Cathedral office, of the liturgy of the hours. It also helps student to gain a critical understanding on various liturgical terms, liturgical vessels, books and vestments. Contextualization of liturgy in Chinese/HK contexts will also be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. students will gain critical understanding on the history and theology of sacred worship.
2. students will be able to apply the knowledge gain from this course to their own ecclesiastical context.
3. students will acquire basic but core skills in appropriately performing liturgies.
4. students will be able to develop their own visions on how the liturgical traditions should be contextualized in the Chinese context
courses.course_syllabus:
I Corporate Worship and Church Life; Worship in Truth and Spirit; Worship as Dialogue.
II. Design and Discharge in Worship. The Study of 1 Corinthians 14; The Planning of the Order of Service; Writing of corporate prayers and mediation for the lectionary.
III Worship as Offering; Old Testament Sacrifices, Levitical Priesthood and the Church as a Royal Priesthood.
IV. Time as Communication: The Christian Calendar; the Lectionary；Reading the Bible/ Preaching According to the Lectionary in the Service.
V. Space as Communication; Christian Art and Worship.
VI. Worship as Pastoral Care: The Funeral and the Wedding Service; Special Occasions.
VII. The Sacraments and Corporate Worship—The Rite of Initiation-Holy Baptism.
VIII. The Sacraments and Corporate Worship—The Rite of Continuation— Eucharist.
IX. Worship as a Drama—The Western Roman Catholic tradition; Vatican II Liturgical Reform; Worship as a Journey--The Orthodox Church tradition.
X. The Protestant Tradition: The Normative and Regulative Principles of Liturgical Reforms: Reformed, Lutheran, Anglican.
XI. The Function of Congregational Singing in Corporate Worship; Hymnology

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Preaching
courses.description: Through lectures, reading and self-studies, students learn how to compose and deliver sermon. Special emphasis will be given to Biblical exposition, progression of thoughts, flow of feelings, use of illustrations, relevancy, and deliver styles. Critiques, suggestions, or comments by the instructor and interaction in a small group will be facilitated. Each student is expected to deliver a full-length sermon in front of other students two to three times a semester and hand in the relevant scripts at the same time. Students need to hand in the revised scripts in two weeks’ time.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes: Learn how to compose and deliver sermons of 30 minutes and learn how to make comments and give suggestions to sermons preached by others.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. 課程介紹；宣道者個人靈性、學養、性向與風格的關係
2. 既是宣講，也是做神學(Doing theology)：宣講、神學與處境之關聯
3. 出外觀摩
4. 宣講微技巧
5. 講章類別的撰寫與演繹：釋經講道(Expository preaching)
6. 觀摩與評論1；宣講與修辭技巧
7. 觀摩與評論2；講章類別的撰寫與演繹：主題式講道(Topical preaching)
8. 觀摩與評論3；講章類別的撰寫與演繹：處境講道(Situational preaching)
9. 觀摩與評論4；講章類別的撰寫與演繹：敘事講道(Narrative preaching)
10. 觀摩與評論5；講章類別的撰寫與演繹：佈道式講道(Evangelistic preaching)
11. 觀摩與評論6；宣講與多媒體應用
12. 觀摩與評論7；向不同群體的宣講方式
13. 觀摩與評論8；信仰立場先於政治考量的宣講
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Death and Dying
courses.description: This course explores the meaning of death and its related issues from different perspectives, namely, religious, pastoral, philosophical and sociological in order that students can develop sensitivity and skill in meeting and serving the dying as well as the bereaved.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To understand different perspectives on death and dying.
2. To acquire students with knowledge and necessary skill how to take care of the dying and bereaved.
3. To reinforce values of empathy, hope, courage and solidarity.
4. To become more confidence in skill in academic context via writing and speaking.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Death as a person and an agent of change
2. Movie: The Farewell Party
3. Illness, Suffering and Personhood: A Case of Dementia
4. Chinese New Year Holiday
5. Advance Directives and Euthanasia
6. Caring: Hospital, Hospice and Nursing Home
7. Heterotopia: Cemetery and Funeral Parlour.
8. Good Death: Religion and Funeral Rituals
9. Good Death: Religion and Funeral Rituals (2)
10. Good Bye
11. Life after Death: Silence Teacher Scheme (visit)
12. Good Life: Suicide
13. Death, Violence and Catastrophe
14. Death Education
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Foundation of Religious Education
courses.description:
This course aims at providing opportunities for students:
1. To look at the foundational theories of Religious Education;2. To deepen their knowledge and understanding of such theories from the perspective of the Christian religion;3. To apply such theories in assessing exercises of assessing courses/programs of Christian Education currently used in denominations and local churches;4. To apply such theories by developing a model of Christian Education with a new approach entitled “Praxis in Dimensions”.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Approaches to Mission Studies
courses.description: The course introduces students to the broad subject of mission studies and the understanding of issues related to the mission of the church. In particular it will lead to a deeper understanding about the biblical basis of the mission of the church, about the historical development of Christian mission, about contemporary challenges that the mission of the churches faces, about patterns of mission today, about contextualization, more particularly about mission in the context of Hong Kong and China.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
• The students will develop an understanding of a variety of missionary patterns and paradigms.
• The students will be able to critically review different approaches in Christian mission and evangelism and make informed and appropriate judgment about their contextual character.
• The students will apply their diagnostic skills to evaluate specific mission agencies and organizations from within their ecclesial context.
• The students will learn to creatively design a mission outreach plan to specific people groups.
courses.course_syllabus:
(Session 1)
I. Introduction
What is Mission?
Mission – Ecumenics – Global Christianity
(Session 2)
II. Foundations of Mission
The biblical basis of mission
(Session 3)
The historical development of mission
(Session 4)
Historical developments since the 1950s: The ecumenical and evangelical understanding of mission
(Session 5)
III. Patterns of Mission
Mission as evangelism
(Session 6)
Mission as church planting and church growth: The churchgrowth movement
(Session 7)
World evangelization and frontier mission
(Session 8)
Mission in the context of poverty and injustice
(Session 9)
Mission and inculturation (1): Backgrounds. The gospel and culture
(Session 10)
Mission and inculturation (2): Problems of inculturation and models of inculturation
(Session 11)
IV. Issues and Challenges of Mission in the Present
The Challenge of other faiths
(Session 12)
Mission and communication: How do we communicate the gospel?
(Session 13)
Unfinished business or discussion of practical issues
(depending on time and on interest)
1) Mission in China
2) Short-term mission
3) Mission in Creative Access Countries
4) Mission and money

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Christian Ethics
courses.description: This course examines the context, nature, method and principles of Christian ethics. Emphasis is given to contemporary challenges to and of Christian ethics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To understand the diversities of Christian ethics and its challenges.
2. To acquire students with knowledge to critically reflect the contemporary issues.
3. To make appropriate critical connections between the study of Christian ethics, practical theology and biblical studies.
4. To appreciate the impact that one’s values and decisions make on the lives of oneself and others.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Critiques of morality
2. Religion and morality
3. Theories of Ethics
4. Foundations (1): Jesus Christ and Christian ethics
5. Foundations (2): The Bible and Christian ethics
6. Foundations (3): Natural law and Christian ethics
7. Foundations (4): Religious life and practice
8. Foundations (5): History of Christian Ethics
9. Moral agent (1) : The Church
10. Moral agent (2) : Spirituality and Morality
11. Christian ethics in contexts (1): Different models of Christian ethics
12. Christian ethics in contexts (2): Contemporary challenges
13. Christian ethics in contexts (3): Chinese religious context
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Preaching Bible in Contexts
courses.description: The course encourages and equips contextual interpretation and contextual proclamation of the Bible. "Contexts" are existential, life-oriented and multifaceted, e.g. political, economic, cultural, geographical, religious, personal growth, etc. "Context" could also be determined by liturgical demands such as Sunday sermon, baptism, Eucharist, festival, funeral, wedding ceremony and so forth. Students are expected to bridge the ancient biblical context(s) with the contemporary life context(s).

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Homiletics and Selected Reading of the Bible
courses.description: The course encourages dialogue between pastors and biblical scholar(s) concerning theory and praxis. Both parties are engaged to build up a constructive relationship between critical exegesis and ecclesiastical preaching. Sermon topic related to specific area of biblical studies (such as Wisdom Literature, Pauline Letters, the Apocalypse of John, etc.) will be selected. Instead of motivational speaking, students are expected to prepare and deliver sermons in light of scholarly consensus, updated biblical studies and accountable exposition of the Bible.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Teaching Bible in Church and School
courses.description: The course investigates the history, current situation and new trends of educational ministry within the Church and schools with church background (including local churches, denominations, kindergartens, primary schools and secondary schools). Implementation experiences of "Sunday" school, Bible study group and religious studies subjects at school are consolidated and evaluated. Strategies for better implementation of Bible teaching are formulated. Students are expected to manage and plan the Bible ministries in their church or school setting effectively.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: The Bible and Worship
courses.description: The course concerns itself with the liturgical study of selected psalms, the investigation of the Sitz im Leben of the church in worship; much attention will be given to the didactic materials bearing on corporate worship in the Bible and their application for today’s church.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge outcome: The student will study the Scriptures especially the psalms against the context in order to develop a biblical understanding of worship.

Attitude outcome: The student is asked to cultivate an openness and personal vulnerability to the biblical sources.

Skill outcome: The student is expected to think biblically in the planning and conduct of corporate worship.

Week 9: Biblical Theology of Worship

Week 10: Art and Space of Worship in the Bible

Week 11: Time of Worship in the Bible

Week 12: Bible in Worship of the Church I: Psalms and Corporate Worship

Week 13: Bible in the Elements of Worship Service

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Theology of Worship
courses.description: Worship is styled as theologia prima, and doctrine as theologia secunda；not a few hymnic and confessional materials are found in the New Testament. The course will discuss various theologies of worship, the pastoral therapeutic efficacy of the sacraments, the functions of signs and symbols bearing on worship.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge outcome: The student is asked to cultivate a more theological understanding of why we are doing what in the conduct of Christian worship.

Attitude outcome: The student is expected to nurture a sense of sacredness and respectfulness wherever he/she finds himself/ herself towards the people and the world.

Skill outcome: The study of theology of worship is not only academic, but for personal enrichment, spiritual growth.
courses.course_syllabus:
Week 1 - Biblical resources and theology of worship—Old Testament.

Week 2 - Biblical resources and theology of worship—New Testament.

Week 3 - Dogma and doxology; rule of prayer and rule of belief.

Week 4 - The Eschatological character of worship; human pathos yearning for divine ethos in worship.

Week 5 - Worship as prayer: praising, thanking and blessing; invoking and beseeching;
Week 6 - Worship as prayer: lamenting and confessing.

Week 7 - Communion of saints: the sanctorale in church calendar and feasts of saints.

Week 8 - The beautiful and the Holy—aesthetics and worship; symbols and signs.

Week 9 - The sacraments being the earthly elements and heavenly reality.

Week 10 - The Eucharist and the consecration of the world.

Week 11- For the sake of the work--worship and ethics and intercession.

Week 12 - The Lamb of God—mystery, suffering and reconciliation.

Week 13 - The Pantocrator—Advent and Eschaton; hope and triumph.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Congregational Hymns and Pastoral Care
courses.description: The course concerns itself with the criteria and evaluation of congregational hymns and their liturgical function in corporate worship; the selection of congregational hymns for the church calendar and theme of worship; their dual function of expression and impression for pastoral care.

courses.learning_outcomes:
The Student will be able to:

1. Be familiar with the function and role of hymns in the corporate worship and Christian life.

2. Select hymns with theological, liturgical, and pastoral discernment.

3. Deal with issues regarding congregational songs of the 21st century as a theologian and pastor.

Week 12: Congregational Songs and life of the Church

courses.title: Planning and Leading Worship Service
courses.description: This course explores the practical ways of planning and leading public worship service of our time applying the reflections of biblical and historical perspectives of worship. Special attention will be given to diverse expressions of worship elements, creative ways of leading corporate worship, and evaluation of current worship practices. Students collaborate to plan and lead worship service.
