courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Church Organist Training
courses.description: The class discusses the skills and techniques of hymn playing and anthem accompanying on the organ. Students will learn how to combine organ repertoire into church liturgies, and also explore different styles of service playing from the Baroque period to the modern time. Students can take this course for up to 3 terms (total of 3 credits). Pianists are welcomed to register for the course but an audition will be required.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
The student is expected to develop a high proficiency in music making, and be able to lead a worship service through music. Throughout the term, the student will look into a special topic that is related to the history of organ/ service playing (e.g. registrations of Bach chorale preludes, French Organ Mass of the 17th Century, Tradition of Hymns and Anthems Playing in England in the 19th Century, etc)

The student should also be self-motivated and practise the assigned organ pieces diligently on a daily basis.
courses.course_syllabus:
Depending on the technique, sight-reading and aural skill of individual student, here are some topics to be explored by the student (student working on different areas simultaneously each week) throughout the time of their organ study.

Area A:

On Hymn Playing

- improvising an introduction for hymn

- improvising a prelude or postlude on a given hymn tune

- reharmonizing hymn tunes

- improvising on interludes

- transposing to a new key for a hymn

- choosing appropriate registrations, tempi for hymns

- knowing the background the hymn text and hymn writers

Area B:

Anthem Playing

- be able to watch the conducting patterns

- be able to work with instrumentalists and singers

- conducting and playing at the console

- transcribing from piano scores

- changing registrations while accompanying on the organ

- choosing appropriate registrations for anthems

Area C:

Organ Literature and Repertoire

- history of the organ

- history of organ playing in church worships

- organ tablatures

- organ repertoire from the Medieval Period- Contemporary

- history of organ building

- different schools (e.g. North German style, French Romantic) of organ repertoire

- historical methods

- different genres (e.g. German Pareludium, German chorale-preludes, French organ mass)

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Preaching According to the Lectionary
courses.description: Preaching according to the lectionary is a time-honored tradition of the church. The four lessons of Old Testament, Psalm, Epistle and the Gospel for the Sunday are carefully arranged to be read and preached according to the liturgical year. The course concerns itself with the liturgical, spiritual import as well as the pastoral application of the lectionary for today’s church alongside the understanding of the basics and recent discussions of homiletics.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
Learning outcome: Students learn to appreciate the spiritual, liturgical import as well as the inter-connection of the four lessons of the Psalm, Old Testament, Epistle and the Gospel.

Attitude outcome: Student should appreciate the ecumenical endeavor and collaboration in the production of the revised common lectionary and resourceful heritage of the faith community.

Skill outcome: Student is expected to dwell on the liturgical import of the lectionary in the preparation of the sermon.
courses.course_syllabus:
Session 1 Introduction to the course; The Church calendar and lectionary for the planning of the pulpit and as resources for the sermon preparation;
Reading: Fuller, Preaching the Lectionary, xvii-xxxi, Series A Advent Season, 1-13 ; Pfatteicher, 105-141.

Session 2 Requisites for effective preaching. Reading: Robinson, 9-30 (Chinese translation, 5-28).

Session 3 The text, big ideas, subject, title, proposition, objective

Reading: Christian Year (CY), 3-29; Robinson, 31-113 (29-111)

(From the fourth session onward, students take turn to deliver the sermon and participate in evaluation of the sermons before the instructor give his own critique.

Students are required to prepare and deliver a homily of twenty minutes according to the lectionary of an assigned Sunday in the class with class evaluation.)

Session 4 Preaching in Advent, Christmastide and the Epiphany; Formal elements of the sermon; the plan and division.

Reading: Robinson, 115-134 (113-133).

Session 5 Preaching in Pre-Lent and Lent; Formal elements of the sermon; introduction, conclusion, transition.

Reading: Robinson, 159-173 (159-174).

Session 6 Preaching the Holy Week; Functional elements of the sermon: explanation, argument, application, illustration.

Reading: Robinson, 137-156 (135-158).

Session 7 Preaching the Eastertide; The Style of the sermon: nature and importance of style; writing of sermons; imagination in preaching.

Reading: Robinson, 191-209 (193-211).

Session 8 Preaching in the Trinity Season; The delivery of sermons: methods, voice and body in delivery.

Reading: Robinson, 191-209 (193-211).

Sessions 9-12

Delivery of sermons and evaluation.

Session 13

Presentation of article reviews

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Religious Education and Personal Growth
courses.description: This course will attempt to study some of the modern developmental theories such as Piaget’s cognitive developmental theory, Erikson’s socio-psychological theory, Kohlberg’s moral developmental theory and Fowlers’ faith developmental theory. Special attention will be given to the evaluation of their signifi cance to education in a religious context.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing the course, students should be able to:
a. comprehend the developmental themes throughout the life span and the related theories of developmental psychology.
b. understand the theories related to moral, faith and spiritual development.
c. self-examine the student’s own understanding and philosophy of religious education.
d. self-examine the student’s stage of personal and spiritual development, reflecting on the implications for her/his role as a religious educator.
e. critically apply concepts in developmental psychology to specific educational contexts.

2. Who Am I and the Quest of Meaning (I): Cross-Cultural and Religious Perspective
3. Who Am I and the Quest of Meaning (II): Psychological Interpretations
Part II: Virtues for Spiritual Growth
4. Beauty – An Ethical Guide in Life
5. Freedom – Giving the Stuff up
Part III: Virtues for Relationship Growth
6. Friendship and Love
7. Wisdom with Others
8. Earth – Our Home
Part IV: Facing the Shadow and the Boundary
9. Anger – the discomforting opportunity
10. Grief, Loss, Death and Dying (Guest Speaker; To be Confirmed)
11. Hope – the Courage to Be
Part V: Reflection and Application

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Culture, Religion and Ethics
courses.description: This course attempts to articulate the creative inquiry into and conceptual interrelationship among culture, religion and ethics. Particular attention is given to the relevance of theological reflection for cultural analysis in public life, the advance of technology, the movement of economic order, the ambiguity of sexual issue and the pressing demands for dialogue between the world’s religions.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To adopt multi-disciplinary approaches to identify, analyze and evaluate the common concerns of culture, religion and ethics.

2. To develop appropriate manner, honest exchange of idea and skill to solve problems in group discussions.

3. To use public reasoning to communicate the findings to a range of audiences.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Religion and Ecological Crisis
courses.description:
This course aims at introducing the students to the issues related to religion and
environmental ethics. The course will cover the following aspects: the basic approaches in environmental ethics; how religions are related to the environmental problems; the worldview and ethics of the major religious traditions; and how contemporary religions respond to the environmental question.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To identify and review critically the relationship between ecology and religion.

2. To apply the knowledge and skill developed in the course creatively to design religious responses to environmental questions.

3. To develop appropriate manner, honest exchange of idea and skill to solve problems in group discussions.

4. To make formal presentation on the theme of religion and ecological crisis to the public.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: THEORIES OF RELIGIOUS EDUCATION
courses.description: This course examines various theories of religious education. It begins with an historical overview of different approaches to religious education. It then examines some influential theories of religious education, particularly James Fowler's comprehensive theory of faith development, Paulo Freire's praxis approach to education, and Thomas Groome's theory of Christian religious education. Students will explore contributions, as well as limitations, of these theories to religious education classroom of contemporary Hong Kong.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Christian Education in the Postmodern World
courses.description: This course explores the dynamics of living in a postmodern world and its impact on Christian education. It will first describe the emergence and meaning of postmodernity. It will then explore its impact on religion in general and Christian education in particular. Issues like religious convictions, moral decisions, and character and spiritual formation will be of particular interest. Lastly, students are expected to rediscover the meanings of Christian education in the postmodern world.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.course_syllabus:
Part I: Background – Postmodern Thoughts
1. Course Introduction, The phenomena of Postmodern thought
2. The background and development of Postmodern thought (1)
3. The background and development of Postmodern thought (2)
Part II: Christian Education in the Postmodern World
4. Plurality, Truth and Sacred Scripture
5. Ambiguity, Personal Faith and Identity
6. Ambiguity, Moral Norms, and Social Justice
7. Fostering Hope: Christian Education in the Postmodern Age
Part III: Pedagogical Shift in Christian Education
8. Pedagogical Shift (1): From Christian Education to Spiritual Education
9. Pedagogical Shift (2): From Learning for Personal Salvation to Learning for Holistic Life
10. Pedagogical Shift (3): From Biblical Knowledge to Self- Awareness and Holistic Growth
11. Pedagogical Shift (4): From Personal Faith to Understanding of Other
12. Developing Spiritual Schools and Churches
13. Conclusion

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Teaching/Learning Theories in Christian Education
courses.description: This course explores theories of teaching and learning in an effort to enhance teaching effectiveness in the field of Christian Education. Attention will be given to the examination of historical and contemporary models of teaching/learning and, the development of personal pedagogies for Christian Education in schools and churches.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing the course, students should be able to:
1. understanding the role of Christian Education in wider cultural, social, and educational contexts; and its cross-curricular significance in schools
2. develop creative and imaginative teaching and learning strategies in Christian Education through cross-curricular approaches
3. critically explore how Christian Education can inform school curriculum, organization, teaching, educational leadership, and student culture.

2. Why do we teach: Christian Education Foundations
3. Where do we Teach: Culture is a Key

7. Christian Education in Pluralistic Cultural Society: Shared Praxis Approach
8. Critical Pedagogy and Christian Education: Paul Freire’s Critical Pedagogy
9. Pedagogical Shift: From Christian Education to Spiritual Education
10. Fostering Hope: Christian Education in the Postmodern Age
11. Conclusion: Paper Writing

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Christian Education and Character Formation
courses.description: This course is designed to equip educators with vision and accompanying skills for aligning Christian education to character formation. Students will be guided in developing a general understanding of how character is formed in childhood and throughout the lifespan. Different psychological and philosophical theories of moral/character development, including Maslow, Erikson, Kohlberg, Gilligan, and McIntyre will be examined. Also, students will be assisted in developing practical strategies and methodologies for supporting character development in the context of Christian Education.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing the course, students should be able to:
a. examine their self’s own understandings and philosophies of moral character formation in Christian education.
b. develop a critical understanding of theories and rationales underlying approaches of moral character education.
c. identify ways in implementation of moral character education in Churches and in Christian schools.
d. apply concepts in moral character education to specific ministry contexts.
e. critique theories of moral character education by participant observation and empirical research.

1. Introduction and Overview
2. Christian Education and Character Formation: Overview
3. Aristotle’s and Aquinas’ Cardinal Virtues
4. Kohlberg and Gilligan
5. Nel Noddings
6. Hauerwas
7. Hauerwas
8. Character Strengthens and Positive Psychology
9. Characters for Care of the Self and Others: Encounter with Ricoeur and Foucault
10. Teaching Strategies for Character Formation in Christian Education
11. Synthesis and Reflection (1)
12. Synthesis and Reflection (2)
13. Synthesis and Reflection (3)
14. Conclusion

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Methods and Paradigms of Christian Studies
courses.description: This course aims at providing students with a solid methodological and theoretical understanding of the multidisciplinary study of Christianity. It mainly introduces the students to the principal tasks (e.g., historical, constructive, practical) and methods, together with their theoretical presuppositions, of Christian studies. It also acquaints students with major theological paradigms (e.g., traditional, liberal, liberationist, feminist, etc.) and their different visions of the theological disciplines (e.g., biblical studies, history of Christianity, systematic theology, pastoral studies, etc.). Issues such as the relation of Christian studies to other academic fields, the alleged conflict between its scientific and ecclesial orientations, and the interconnection of its diverse disciplines, will be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA in Christian Studies and MA in Religious Studies programmes.
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To obtain a broadened and deepened understanding of the major traditions of Christianity in the world in historical and comparative perspectives
2. To be able to understand major theological paradigms in Christianity with their internal complexity, and be able to extend such understanding to issues in church and society
3. To have some knowledge of the tasks and methods of the major disciplines in Christian studies and be able to apply such knowledge in research
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction. Christianity as Multi- Paradigmatic.
2. Historical-Theological Paradigms (1): Early Jewish-Christian Apocalyptic; Patristic Hellenistic Orthodox
3. Historical-Theological Paradigms (2): Mediaeval Latin Roman Catholic; Reformation Protestant.
4. Theological Research and Paper Writing
5. The Tasks and Methods of Biblical Studies
6. The Tasks and Methods of History of Christianity
7. Historical-Theological Paradigms (3): Modernity; Liberal Theology; Neo-Orthodox Theology.
8. Historical-Theological Paradigms (4): Evangelicalism; Pentecostalism
9. The Tasks and Methods of Systematic Theology
10. Historical-Theological Paradigms (5): Liberation Theology; Feminist Theology.
11. The Tasks and Methods of Practical Theology
12. Global Christianity in the 21st century
13. Interdisciplinary approaches to Christian Studies

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: New Testament in Contexts
courses.description: This course will select some texts of the New Testament with contemporary methods for in-depth study. Texts include selected themes of the Pauline Epistles, Synoptic Gospels and Johannine Literature, e.g., Pauline Epistle Form, Doctrinal and Ethical Teachings; Eucharist, Baptism, Miracles and Teachings of the Synoptics; as well as Revelation structure, “I am saying”, Farewell Discourse of the Gospel of John.
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Exclusion=Not for students who have taken THEO5312 Introduction to the New Testament
For students in MA Religious Studies or MA Christian Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
Expected Knowledge Outcomes
1. Know how to find reliable and trustworthy resources for their own reconstruction of socio-historical contexts of the New Testament;
2. Compare and contrast New Testament studies in public domain with uncritical voices by means of established paradigms and academic consensus;
Expected Skills Outcome
3. Analyze context(s) behind primary texts and evaluate their relevance in biblical exegeses; (\* This also serve as a preparation of key research skills for graduate work in advanced biblical studies)
Expected Attitude Outcome
4. Deepen their critical and yet sympathetic understanding of earliest Christian traditions in our contemporary contexts and appraise their contributions in shaping different cultures.

and Greco-Roman culture in the first century, textual criticism, source criticism, form criticism,

contents; crises and messages)
• Other Writings (Pastoral Epistles, Peter’s Letters, Hebrews, Revelation; hostile contexts, church
formation in the world, hope beyond now)

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Contextual Interpretation of the Bible
courses.description: This course introduces some methodologies to read the Bible texts, where the perspectives of readers take primary focus. Defined by their specific contexts such as social, political, historical, philosophical and theological ones, it instructs how one can interpret the Bible meaningfully for their communities of faith. Some of these include postcolonial and post-imperialist interpretations, ethnic interpretations, and interpretations for the disabled, etc. Emphases are given to how these methodologies come about and has developed in the academic disciplines, the components of these methodologies and how they may be applied to the reading of the Bible.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Describe and explain the historical, political, social, cultural and economic contexts of particular communities.
2. Review and analyse the scholarship of the biblical text/s and theology, and explain how traditional interpretations of the Bible in Christian history marginalize and oppress these communities.
3. Delineate the history of oppression of these communities by Christian theology and interpretations.
4. Review and evaluate how recent scholarship in Contextual Interpretations of the Bible contributes to specific communities. Point out the specific contributions as well as criticize the limitations. Make judgments on the relevance and significance of such interpretations, taking seriously as well the contexts of the biblical books.
5. Construct and propose a re-interpretation of a bible passage/book for a specific marginalized community, taking into their contexts as primary focus and finding points of relevance in the biblical passage/book.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Biblical interpretation in the western scholarship
2. New Literary Criticism in Biblical Interpretation
3. African Contextual Biblical Interpretation
4. Post-colonial Biblical Interpretation
5. Interpretation of the Bible for Disabilities
6. Ecological Interpretation of the Bible
7. Interpretation of the Bible for Marginalized Communities
courses.feedback_evaluation: Students are welcome to give their feedback to the teacher throughout the course. There will be a final Evaluation conducted by the University at the end of the course.

3. Essays/Articles/Book listed in the Course Schedule below.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Biblical Theology
courses.description: Exegetical study of Old Testament and New Testament passages and their implication for contemporary church and society.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Review and list the major biblical theologians of the 20th century and their contributions.
2. Analyse and evaluate with specific historical events the reliability and relevance of their biblical theological formulations.
3. Comment and draw implications how some of the significant theologians effect the academia of Biblical Studies as well as churches/denominations of their time.
4. Critically review some of the controversial dogmas in relation to biblical theology. Point out and substantiate the exegetical fallacies and propose what it should be.
5. Distinguish ‘cultural memory’ in biblical studies and draw relevance to biblical theology.
6. Design and propose an outline of a biblical theology that factor in biblical criticisms as well as make it relevant to specific faith communities of today.
courses.course_syllabus:
week1:
1. Syllabus
2. Introduction to “Biblical Theology”
week2:
Biblical Hermeneutics from the Reformation to the Enlightenment
week3:
The Origins of “Biblical Theology”
1. J. P. Gabler’s oration in 1787
2. “What It meant” and “What It Means”
3. Descriptive vs. normative
week4:
Historical-Genetic Approach and History-of-Religion Approach
week5:
Before and Since Karl Barth
1. 18th and 19th century Hermeneutics
2. The influence of dialectic Theology
3. The notion of revelation
week6:
Issues: Theology and history; systemization; the use of central theme as an organizing principle
week7:
Issues: Theology, history, and story; “Salvation History” as the topos of revelation
week8:
Issues: The Unity of OT and NT; Christianization of the OT; and “Christotelic” interpretation of the OT
week9:
Canonical Approach to Biblical Theology; alternative methods
Issues: Biblical Theology as a Christian Enterprise? An Academic Discipline?
week10;
1. Block/Book/Layer and Thematic Approaches to Biblical Theology
2. Biblical Theology and Process Theology
week11:
Doing Biblical Theology in a postmodern, pluralistic, and glocal contexts
week12;
Social Locations and Personal Experience:
week13:
Concluding Remarks

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Methods and Biblical Interpretation
courses.description: Biblical interpretation does not happen in a vacuum. Every interpretive act involves the text, the reader, and its signifying context, including that of the writer(s) and that of the reader, defined by the complex web of social, cultural, political, and even psychological forces. This course covers some major methods used in the critical study of the Bible (with a focus on the Hebrew Bible/Old Testament) from the late nineteenth century to the early twenty-first century, including the historical-critical methods, literary criticism, and reader-centered approaches. It examines the tasks, presuppositions, and reading strategies of various exegetical methods, and evaluates each’s weaknesses and strengths.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA in Christian Studies, Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
After completing this course, students should be able to:
• Describe and compare various critical methods of biblical studies
• Deepen their awareness of how the writer’s and interpreter’s social, cultural, political, and even psychological contexts may affect the process of signification
• Demonstrate a familiarity of the current approaches to biblical interpretation
• Be able to apply at least seven of the critical methods in their reading of the biblical texts
• Be able to formulate their own intersectional and interdisciplinary approach to biblical interpretation
courses.course_syllabus:
Topics:
Week 1) Introduction
Week 2) 1. Historical Criticism, 2. Textual Criticism
Week 3) 3. Source Criticism, 4. Form Criticism
Week 4) 5. Tradition-Historical Criticism, 6. Redaction Criticism
Week 5) 7. Canonical Approach, 8. Folkloristics
Week 6) 9. Rhetorical Analysis, 10. Rhetorical (or Communicative) Criticism
Week 7) 11. Structuralist Criticism, 12. Deconstructive Criticism
Week 8) 13. Reader-Response Criticism, 14. Ideological Criticism
Week 9) 15. Feminist (and Womanist) Criticism, 16. Cultural Criticism and Cross-Textual (and Cross-Cultural) Hermeneutics
Week 10) 17. Social-Scientific Criticism, 18. Socio-Rhetorical Interpretation
Week 11) 19. Narrative Criticism and Narratology
Week 12) 20. Postcolonial Criticism, 21. Queer (or Gender) Criticism
Week 13) 22. Psychological Criticism, Conclusion

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: The Hebrew Bible in Contexts
courses.description: "This course aims at introducing students to the approaches to reading the Hebrew Bible (The Christian Old Testament) in its literary, socio-political and religio-cultural contexts. The literary setting and historical background will be surveyed and explored in order to enhance students’ understanding of the text and the dynamics of the reading process."
courses.enrollment_requirement:
Exclusion=Not for students who have taken THEO5311 Introduction to the Hebrew Bible
For students in MA Christian Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
Knowledge Outcomes
(1) Describe
a. what the study of Hebrew Bible constitutes.
b. with the help of resources, the general background and contexts of the biblical books.
(2) Explain
a. the necessity of understanding contexts of when studying the Hebrew Bible.
b. the literary, socio-political and religio-cultural contexts of a specified period in biblical history.
c. the necessity and limitations in biblical scholarship for reconstructing contexts.
(3) Distinguish
a. what is “historical Israel” and “biblical Israel”.
b. the different contexts for interpreting scriptures.
(4) Recite the main historical epochs of biblical Israel.
(5) Examine and analyse the contexts of a given text using quality resources.
(6) Sketch an interpretation of a given text integrating a current context to a passage in the Hebrew Bible.
(7) Comment and evaluate on those information that were presented differently in church. Determine the consequences of the information.
(8) Reflect and discuss on the implications of academic study and its impact on faith-based communities.
(9) Construct interpretations that take the contexts of the biblical text/s seriously and also relevant to one’s context.
Attitude Outcomes:
(1) Appreciate by listing the contributions of the diverse interpretations of scriptures throughout history and their historical and contextual developments.
(2) Respect for the historical development of Old Testament scholarship in its entirety by pointing out their relevance to current contexts – within the communities of faith and also within the academia.
(3) Develop keen insights to read texts meaningfully and responsibly by reading up and constructing different contextual interpretations of biblical texts – for the sake of peace and justice, understanding and acceptance to all humanity and living creatures of God’s creation.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Course Introduction: The Awareness of the Context(s); OT vs. HB Canon
2. Ancient Contexts: Archaeology and Mythology (Genesis)
3. Ancient Contexts: History, History Writing and Historiography (Exodus)
4. The Nature of Criticism (Leviticus and Numbers)
5. Ancient Context: Literary Convention in the Ancient World (Samuel-Saul-David)
6. Ancient Contexts: The Empire and the Exile (Second Temple literature)
7. Ancient Contexts: Social studies and Socio-Economic Contexts (the Book of the Twelve)
8. Contemporary Contexts: Modern mind as context (Joshua and Judges; SOS)
9. Contemporary Contexts: Post-Modernity as context (Job and Qohelet)
10. Contemporary Contexts: Judaism and the Church as context; Term Paper Proposal (Ruth)
11. Contemporary Contexts: The Public Space as context (Jeremiah)
12. The Reception of the Texts (Isaiah)
13. A Retrospect and a proposal
courses.feedback_evaluation: Two course evaluations will be conducted. The first will be done midway through the course, which is tailored to facilitate better progress through the course. The second one will be conducted by the university-wide exercise.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Contextual Theologies
courses.description: This course tries to critically examine several features of all theological endeavours: particularity, contextuality and historicity. It also articulates how theologies are spatially and temporally shaped. Accordingly, the relationship between theology and context will not be conceived as a kind of linear application of some ready-made theologies to the contemporary contexts, but a kind of interpretive effort which tries to correlate the Christian traditions with the contemporary cultural, socio-political and economical context. It will also discuss the practical dimension of the ‘doing’ of theologies. It is according to all this that some examples of contextual theology will be introduced.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
courses.course_syllabus:
1 定位
1. 1 甚麼是處境神學？
1. 2 信仰（福音）與政治之關係—以聖經詮釋/釋經為例子
1. 2.1 意識型態批判：對意識型態及結構性罪惡之批判：可 12:42-44
1. 2.2 天國的政治含意：天國、天國對邊緣人的偏愛、對不公平之抗衡
1. 2.2.1 天國裡的人：可十13-16等
1. 2.2.2 對公平的訴求：約八1-11
1. 2.2.3 天國之介入、耶穌之生死、救恩
1. 2.3 抗爭(resistance)：可一1之政治曖昧抗爭策略（後殖解讀）
1. 2.4 總論：新約聖經中對政治（權力）的三種態度
1. 3 信仰（福音）與歷史及文化經驗
1. 3.1 以聖經詮釋/釋經為例子
1. 3.1.1 基於歷史經驗的信點：以一神論之歷史沿革為例
1. 3.1.2 另類文化實踐：以路七36-50之女性身體為例
1. 3.2 詮釋學與歷史文化經驗的糾結：以聖經權威為例
1. 3.3 基督與文化的關係類型
1. 4 處境神學的歷史沿革
1. 5 Stephen B. Bevans 的六個處境神學類型
1. 6 從基督宗教藝術看基督宗教的多元現實
2 處境神學之實例—選讀
2. 1 拉丁美洲之解放神學
2. 2 後殖民神學
2. 3 亞洲神學
2. 4 香港處境下的神學沉思
2. 5 婦女神學
2. 6 歐陸批判神學
3 處境神學—幾個〔系統〕神學考慮
3. 1 耶穌論／基督論
3. 2 上帝論
3. 3 罪
3. 4 教會論

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Modern Christian Thinkers
courses.description: The course introduces the work and thought of some of the important theologians of the 20th century. Western thought since the period of the Enlightenment has understood human beings as autonomous from God. Modern science and human rationality left no place for God. The course attempts to understand how Christian faith and theology reacts to this challenge of modernity by presenting and studying different theological responses to it. The course puts emphasis on the reading of primary sources of various theologians.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Christian Studies and Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
• The students will be able to critically engage with difficult texts of modern Christian thinkers.
• The students will learn to critically evaluate the soundness of different approaches to modern society and make appropriate judgment about multiple theological perspectives.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction to the course; Modernity and Modern Culture – Modernity and Beyond; Background of 20th Century Theology: The Liberal Theology of the 19th Century
2. Neo-Orthodox Reaction to Modernity: Karl Barth and the Theology of Crisis
3. Karl Barth (continue)
4. Existentialist Theology: Rudolf Bultmann
5. Radical Incarnational Theology: Dietrich Bonhoeffer
6. Bonhoeffer (continue)
7. Secular Ecumenism: Harvey Cox
8. Correlation: Paul Tillich
9. History and Eschatology: Moltmann
10. Liberation Theology: Gutierrez
11. Feminist Theology: Rosemary Radford Ruether
12. Postliberal and Postmodern Theology and Outlook; Student presentations

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Asian Theologies
courses.description: Asia is a large continent with the largest population in the world and a diverse cultural heritage. Though Christianity was born in West Asia, its expansion to South and East Asia happened rather recently. In the last few decades, Asians have begun to utilize their own resources and context in theological endeavour. This course attempts to investigate some of the theologies emerging in Asia.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.course_syllabus: This course offers a broad survey of Asian theologies combined with more tightly focused treatment of examples of writing from selected Asian Christian thinkers.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Christianity in Chinese Religious Context
courses.description: This course aims at studying Chinese Christianity in the Chinese religious context. Special emphasis will be given to the question as to how Christianity has been viewed in and shaped by the Chinese religious context. Comparison between some of the Chinese Christian phenomena and their counterparts in the traditional Chinese religions will be made, e.g., the Taiping Christianity vis-à-vis the Buddhist or Taoist Messianic movements. Issues on Christianity faces in the Chinese religious context will also be discussed, e.g., syncretism and dual religious citizenship.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.course_syllabus:
1. 道德生命的探索：中國哲學思想的開展與特質
2. 先秦儒學（1）：孔子的道德社會秩序與基督教的「人學」建構 — 論「內聖外王」之道
3. 先秦儒學（2）：孟子的「性善論」與基督教的「原罪論」— 論人性與天道
4. 宋明儒學：程朱、陸王的「已發、未發」修養工夫與基督教的靈修學體驗 —修養與「他者」
5. 新儒學：唐君毅、牟宗三的「道德理想主義」與基督教的救恩論 — 論「自力」與「他力」
6. 道家（老、莊）的人生哲學（1）：境界與修養工夫
7. 道家（老、莊）的人生哲學（2）：道、自然與基督教的文化神學
8. 印度佛學（原始佛教、中觀學、唯識學）：解脫之道
9. 中國佛學（1）：華嚴宗與天台宗的「判教」與境界
10. 中國佛學（2）：禪宗的基督教意義

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Christianity and Social Change
courses.description: In the absence of any social theory that is uniquely “Christian”, this course will seek to study the positions of the Christian churches on various political and social issues as they seek to define for themselves their role in a rapidly changing world. Asian models and the more traditional Western approaches to similar issues will be compared in order to highlight the strength and weaknesses of each in the common attempt to balance the Christian ideal and social realities.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, the student will (i) obtain a basic understanding of the major characteristics of modern society in several dimensions, the processes of social change leading to such characteristics, and the impact on Christianity; (ii) understand how Christian churches, organizations, and individuals in several social, cultural, and historical situations have responded to social changes in modernity; (iii) be acquainted with the critical analysis of modernity by a few social theorists; (iv) critically analyze the relation between Christianity and social change about a case, event, or issue in modernity, and constructively articulate a response.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: Modernity, Social Change, and Christianity
2. Modernity I: Capitalism
3. Modernity II: Nationalism
4. Modernity III: Social and Cultural Aspects
5. Modernity IV: Religious Aspects
6. Modernity V: Globalization
7. Modernity VI: Pathologies of Modernity
8. Christianity and Social-Economic Changes I: Social Christianity and the Social Gospel
9. Christianity and Social-Economic Changes II: Christian conservatism and liberation theology
10. Ecumenical Responses to Social Changes: The World Council of Churches and the Roman Catholic church
11. Christianity and Social-Political Changes I: Nazi Germany and South Africa
12. Christianity and Social-Political Changes II: China and Hong Kong
13. Christianity and Social-Political Changes III: Hong Kong

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Chinese Christianities
courses.description: This course examines various issues regarding the course of Christianity indigenization and contextualization in China, such as the development of Nestorian Christianity in Tang Dynasty, Jesuits mission and the Rites Controversy, the issue of Chinese Bible translation and Christian literature, Christianity and social reform and reconstruction in China, independent churches and evangelists in China, and the issue of Christianity and races. By discussing the above issues, this course shall explore how the Chinese experience would contribute to the enrichment of church universal.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
Students are expected to, by the end of the course,
1. Show their concrete knowledge of certain terms and concepts, such as indigenization, contextualisation, localisation, inculturation and interculturation.
2. Be able to critically reflect on issues regarding Christianity indigenization in China from historical perspectives.
3. Demonstrate their abilities to reflect on and evaluate, from theological perspectives, the efforts towards Christianity indigenization by Chinese Christians.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Christianity and Chinese Culture
courses.description: Starting from the traditional understanding of indigenization whereby culture are often looked upon as static entities, Christianity and Chinese culture will also be compared as they moved through the recent history of China as two living forces competing to shape the China that was to be. This is an open-ended course which will continuously be informed by recent trends and developments.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA Religious Studies or Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
courses.course_syllabus:
〈第1講〉基督教與中國文化：不同層次的相遇
〈第2講〉中國文化結構(1)：經濟結構、政治社會結構、意識形態結構
〈第3講〉中國文化結構(2)：現代化與中國文化結構的轉型
〈第4講〉中國文化的文化神學(1)：政治文化的基督教反思
〈第5講〉中國文化的文化神學(2)： 政治經濟的基督教反思—「社會主義」社會理想、「資本主義」社會理想與人性的建構
〈第6講〉中國的身體、心靈與人際關係(1)：從中國人生哲學到中國人的國民性格
〈第7講〉中國的身體、心靈與人際關係(2)：人情、關係、面子的權力結構分析
〈第8講〉中國的身體、心靈與人際關係(3)：《孫子兵法》與基督教人際關係倫理學的反思
〈第9講〉中國的身體、心靈與人際關係(4)：《黃帝內經》與基督教的養生與養心

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Christianity in Twentieth Century China
courses.description: This course examines the development of Christian thoughts and institutions in China from the early twentieth century to the present.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
By the end of the course, students are expected to
1. Recognize the basic knowledge of several important issues regarding the development of Christianity in twentieth century China.
2. Demonstrate their understanding of the interactive relationships between Christianity and socio-political context in modern and contemporary China.
3. Show a deeper understanding of the historical causes behind the status quo of Christianity in China.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. 中華歸主：傳教事業與中國教會的建立
2. 風潮湧動：二十世紀前期的政教關係
3. 安身立命：中國教會自我意識的求索
4. 人間天國：社會福音與救國救世
5. 道成肉身：中國民間基督教的興起
6. 戰火浮生：中日戰爭時期的中國基督教
7. 曲終人散：西方來華傳教運動的終結
8. 反帝愛國：紅色政治洪流下的中國基督教
9. 愛國愛教：中國基督教的選擇與命運
10. 世紀傳承：中國基督教的機遇與挑戰〔邢〕
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: History of Christian Thought
courses.description: This course consists of a critical survey of the history of the development of Christian (mainly theological) thought. It will concentrate on analysis of several decisive phrases of development and will attempt to show the interaction between Christian thought and its historical circumstances.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
courses.learning_outcomes: After completing this course, the student is expected (a) to have a solid overview of the development of Christian thought, including the diversity of views, major historical developments, and significant issues involved, and their interrelations; (b) to be able to understand and appreciate some important theologians, including their life and thought; (c) to be able to critically articulate the relevance of Christian thoughts in personal life, churches, and society.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction
1. The definition of the title and the aims and structure of this course
The Early Church and the Formation of Catholicism
2. The emergence of Christianity from the second temple Judaism
3. The way the scriptures were interpreted and the formation of the early tradition
4. The significance and development of early creeds, dogma and doctrines
The Medieval Period and Eastern Thought
5. A brief outline of the development of the Eastern Christian thought
6. Augustine’s thought and his influence: a person one cannot avoid
7. Is the medieval period really dark? Plus a survey of scholasticism and mysticism
The Reformation and its Consequence
8. Is the Reformation really a break? The tension of Christian thought at the time
9. The afterlife of the Reformation: from enchantment to disenchantment?
10. At the dawn of the Enlightenment: Orthodoxy, Rationalism, Pietism, and so on
The Enlightenment and Beyond
11. The challenges of modernity to Christianity and the rise of new thought waves
12. The rapid change of theological drama of the “short” twentieth century
13. The so-called post-modern shift and the search for Christian identity
14. Roundup and conclusion
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Public Theology
courses.description: This course helps students perceive doing theology as taking place within the ethical debates of society as a whole. It introduces different ways of how theology has entered or can entered, both historically and methodologically, into debate on shared ground with social sciences, politics and economics, etc. Different theological perspectives, such as those put forward by Reinhold Niebuhr, Max Stackhouse, and Duncan Forrester on the one hand, and Howard Yoder, Stanley Hauerwas, John Milbank and others, on the other hand, will be discussed. Students will also be shown how these perspectives can be applied to the discussion of local public issues.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To review critically different theological opinions on public theologies.
2. To be engaged into a fruitful dialogue between theology and other disciplines, such as, politics and economics on public life.
3. To correlate the knowledge developed in the course to the Christian practice in Hong Kong, and to evaluate it critically .
4. To use public reasoning to communicate the findings to a range of audiences.
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Introduction: Methodological (1): What Public Theology is: theology and stewardship, authority of pubic theology 。
2. Methodological (2) Church, Faith and Public Theology。
3. Methodological (3) What Public Theology is not:different from political theology, civil religion, and others 。
4. Descriptive (1) Calvinism, Abraham Kuyper, and Worldview 。
5. Descriptive (2) : Abraham Kuyper on Common Grace。
6. Descriptive (3) Abraham Kuyper and Herman Dooyeweerd: Creation Order and Sphere Sovereignty 。
7. Descriptive (4) Reinhold Niebuhr: Christian Realism。
8. Constructive (1) Christian theology and human rights:Trinity, Image of God, and Human Dignity 。
9. Constructive (2) Christian theology and human rights: Love, Justice, and Human Rights。
10. Constructive (3) Christian theology and human rights: Calvinism and human rights。
11. Public Theology in the Chinese Context : Reformed Public Theology in Chinese Churches and Sino-Christian Public Theology 。
12. Conclusion, Presentation & Consultation。
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Theology and Work
courses.description: Work can be a creative expression of the way one professes commitment, service and personal gift to a community. This course is to provide a Christian critique of the contemporary practice of work and retrieve the dignity of work. Concepts related to work like vocation, leisure, play and Sabbath would be discussed.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To evaluate theologically the ideologies and practice of work.
2. To extend the knowledge and skill developed in the course for reflecting a work ethics that upholds human dignity.
3. To use public reasoning to communicate the findings to a range of audiences
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Work: Nature, Scope and Concerns
2. Imposition of work ethics I: rationalization and bureaucraticization
3. Imposition of work ethics II: division of labour and of the human subject
4. From work ethics to aesthetics of consumption I: the working poor
5. From work ethics to aesthetics of consumption II: the end of production and hyperreality
6. Calling to emancipation and creation
7. Theological Survey: Catholic and Protestant
8. Theological Models of Work (1): Work, Leisure and Sabbath
9. Moral Person in an Immoral Society: Ethical Dilemmas in Work (1)
10. Theological Models of Work (2): Vocation, Co-creation and Liberation
11. Theological Models of Work (3): Faith at Work Movement (Individual, Organization, and Social)
12. Experience Sharing (Social Enterprise and Labour Union)
13. Moral Person in an Immoral Society: Ethical Dilemmas in Work (2)

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Media, Popular Culture and Christianity
courses.description: This course is a critical exploration of the intricate relationships between popular media culture and Christianity. While popular culture and the media have long become a daily reality for many in the world, these have seldom been taken seriously by theologians and scholars of religion. Also, the relationship between popular media and religion (including Christianity) is often overlooked in academic studies until relatively recent time. We shall re-examine various manifestations of popular culture from Christian theological perspectives, and also probes into the subtle interrelatedness between media culture and Christianity as an organised religion. As its wider academic context, this course engages with the interdisciplinary field of media, religion, and culture (MRC) which has been under vigorous development since the mid-1990s; as its immediate socio-cultural-religious context of discussions, it attends particularly to the Chinese language popular media and Chinese Christianity in Hong Kong.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in MA in Christian Studies, Master of Divinity and MA in Religious Studies programmes
courses.course_syllabus:
1. Why media, popular culture, and Christianity?

2. Regarding media and popular culture: what popular media cultures are and how they have been studied

3. Reviewing Hong Kong popular culture

4. Relating Media, Popular Culture, and Christianity

5. Images and visual culture – religious and theological dimensions

6. Engaging with images theologically

7. Television, society, and the construction of identities

8. Cinema, narratives, and the cultural turn of theology

9. Advertising, consumerism, and the expressions of faith

10. Google, Facebook, and the revolution in human social existence

11. News, perception, and the reconstruction of reality

12. Renewing Christian Praxis in Media Cultures

13. Re-envisioning Christian Theology in an Age of Mediated Cultures

courses.title: Christian Counselling
courses.description: This course will cover the following areas: 1) the similarities and differences between Christian Counselling and General Counselling; 2) the similarities and differences between Pastoral Counselling and Pastoral Care; 3) different approaches to Christian Counselling; and 4) skills, knowledge and practical competence in Christian Counselling.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction
Christian Counseling vs. General Counseling
Negotiating a Presence-Centred Christian Counselling
Revisiting Empathy
Reframing as a technique
Hope-based counseling
Faith healing, hope, and religious ritual
Sin-based counseling
o Counseling & individual sin
o Counseling & sinned against
Selected topic 1: Crisis counseling
Selected topic 2: Suffering
Selected topic 3: Mindfulness Practices for Christian Counseling
Case illustration
Bereavement counseling
o Disenfranchised grief
o Continuing bond
courses.feedback_evaluation: An end-of-term university-wide course evaluation will be conducted in class. Students’ comments and feedback on the course through e-mail or personal meetings with instructor and/or tutors are always welcomed.
courses.required_readings:
Kwan, Simon Shui-Man. 2016. Negotiating a Presence-Centred Christian Counselling: Towards a Theologically
Informed and Culturally Sensitive Approach. Newcastle, UK: CSP.
Additional Readings: As assigned and distributed in class sessions.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Theology and Counseling Theories
courses.description: This course serves two basic functions: first, to equip students with a basic understanding on the contemporary general counseling theories: second, to enhance students’ competence to read these theories theologically. The methodology adopted will be a kind of mutually critical correlation. Substantively, the course will introduce six to seven contemporary counseling theories, which will be followed by theological critiques on them.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
Aims: The core of this course is built around the interface between theology and “secular” (or general) counseling. It aims to
1. familiarize students with a range of therapeutic models;
2. enhance students’ competence to read these models theologically.
Learning Outcomes:
1. Students gain basic understanding on several models of secular counseling;
2. Students learn the critical skills to theologize counseling theories with a mutually critical correlational perspective.
3. Students start to appreciate the possibilities of integration between social scientific theories and theological traditions.
4. Students gain a basic understanding of the meaning and how-to of reflective practice.
courses.course_syllabus:
Introduction I
1. Introduction: class discussion on Soul and Afterlife
Introduction II
2. Models of Integration between Theology and Secular Sciences
A Recent Trend
3. On “Common Factors Debate”—therapy as religious experience and God as the Healer
Theological reflection on therapeutic models
4. On Person Centered Therapy—Acceptance and God’s Nature
5. On REBT—the experiential language of sin
6. On Gestalt therapy—Theological Reflection on “Presence”
7. On Logo-Therapy—Meaning of Suffering
8. On some forms of healing associated with the New Age Movement (Family Constellation & Hypnosis)—Theology and Paranormality/Parapsychology
9. Narrativity in Counseling and the Problem of the Self—the theology of Imago Dei
Selected Topics
10. Mindfulness, Neuroplasticity and the theology of Religious Experience
11. Intellectual Disability (or Mental Retardation), Theology of Disability, and Theology & Practice of Conversion
12. Class Discussion

courses.title: Theological Studies: Seminar II
courses.description: Discussion in seminar setting on specific issues related to Theological Studies. Students are allowed to take these courses for more than once, and gain the units each time they pass the course. The specific content will be designed by the teacher who offers the courses. Students are allowed to take these courses for more than once.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. To critically review, consolidate, and extend theological knowledge with special reference to one or more selected topics or issues.
2. To analyze, evaluate, and/or synthesize theological ideas, concepts, and perspectives to address critically and constructively certain theological issues.
3. To deepen the understanding of the diversity and complexity of theological positions and perspectives and to make informed judgment in theological studies.

courses.feedback_evaluation: End-of-term university wide course evaluation will be conducted. On-and-off student feedback will be received by supervisor.

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Special Topics on Biblical Studies I
courses.description: This course will examine topics or problems related to Biblical Studies, such as: Pentateuchal Studies, Prophetic Literature, Wisdom and the Psalms, Synoptic Gospels, Johannine Literature, Pauline Letters, Hermeneutics, sociological approaches and historical background of the biblical studies, etc. Students are allowed to take these courses for more than once.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity or MA Christian Studies or MA Theological Studies
courses.learning_outcomes:
Upon completing the course, students should be able to:
1. List the components and describe the complexity of the Biblical Topic.
2. Review past scholarship and comment how the Topic was dealt with.
3. Analyse and evaluate the Topic from various perspectives, such as: New Criticisms of Biblical Interpretations and/or Contextual Interpretations of the Bible.
4. Research on and theorise the relationship between the Topic and the theology or other theological disciplines.
5. Reflect and articulate how this Topic can be relevant in the various contexts.

courses.course_syllabus:
Taking the seminar on “J.S. Bach and the Lutheran Chorales” as an example,

Week 1: Overview of the development of sacred music in the Lutheran tradition

Week 2: Mass settings in the 1500s

Early life of Martin Luther

Week 3: Luther as an Musician

Latin Hymns, Latin Antiphons

Week 4: Luther’s view on Theology and Music

Pre-Reformation Hymns and Psalms

Week 5: Lutheran Chorales

Music in Early Lutheranism

Week 6: Kapellmeister

Function of the Organ in Church Worship

Role of the Organist

Hymn Singing Tradition in Bach’s Era

Week 7: Deutsche Messe (1526)

Bach, from 1685-1707 (Eisenach-Lüneburg- Arnstadt- Mühlhausen)

Clavier-Übung III, BWV 552, 669-689, 802-805

Week 8: Bach, from 1708-1714 (Weimar)

Orgelbüchlein, BWV 599-644

Week 9: Bach, from 1714-1717 (Weimar)

Leipzig-Chorales, BWV 651-668

Week 10:Bach, from 1717-1723 (Cöthen)

St. Matthew Passion, BWV 244

Week 11:Bach, from 1723-1750 (Leipzig)

Cantatas: BWV 1-197, 199

Week 12:Bach, from 1723-1750 (Leipzig)

Mass in B Minor, BWV 232

Chorales in hymnals of our time

Week 13: Bach, from 1723-1750 (Leipzig)

Symbolism an Bach’s sacred works

Introducing chorale-based compositions and congregational singing to church worships

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Theology and Hong Kong Society
courses.description: This course equips students with knowledge and skills in theologizing with an interdisciplinary horizon across a variety of aspects of everyday practical life in Hong Kong. It helps students to see how different sub-disciplines of theology can be critically integrated into a coordinated whole and in this way be relevant to the practical life in one's own context. Social and theological analysis are given equal emphasis, and how these two could be mutually and critically correlated will be demonstrated. Experts or/and experienced practitioners in different fields of practice will be invited to share with students their analyses of the respective public/current issues, while theological responses (philosophical, exegetical, historical, and practical) will be given by teachers from different sub-disciplines in theology. Around half of the lectures will be structured in the form of an interdisciplinary dialogue.
courses.enrollment_requirement: Pre-requisite = THEO5906 Methods and Paradigms of Christian Studies or THEO5336 Systematic Theology II
courses.learning_outcomes:
At the completion of this course, students should be able to achieve the below:

Knowledge Aspect

1. Acquire a general but critical framework to integrate various sub-disciplines of theology for a practical analysis and evaluation of the Hong Kong society.

2. Demonstrate a contextual understanding of a variety of models of publicization of theology.

Skill Aspect

1. Acquire the ability to apply an interdisciplinary approach to a theological analysis and evaluation of the Hong Kong society in some selected aspects (please refer to Course Syllabus).

2. Begin to be able to formulate one's own initial interdisciplinary framework to do contextual theological analyses of one's own place.

Values and Attitudes Aspect

1. Appreciate the importance of an interdisciplinary horizon to any theological understanding of one's own society.

2. Critically aware of the role of theology in public sphere of one's own place.

3. Appreciate the value of defragmentation of theological study.
courses.course_syllabus:
This course will be composed of two core sections.

Core Section 1: Three Major Lenses or Models for understanding the possible ways for theology to engage the public sphere will be introduced briefly. The principal aim of this section is to equip the students with basic frameworks to understand and engage in the dialogical platform that constitutes the second core section.

1. Introduction:

a. David Tracy's "theology as public discourse for public realm" as the theological orientation of Christian faith and praxis.

b. Three kinds of publicness that mark theological discourse.

c. David Tracy’s notion of “the public at large” and its relationship with practical theology.

d. The tradition of the public relevance of theology.

e. A practical-prophetic ecclesiology.

2. Public Theology as a Dialogical Lens

a. What is public theology?

b. Models of public theology as advanced by Eneida Jacobsen.

c. Local examples.

3. Practical Theology as a Dialogical Lens

a. Practical theology as a transformative discourse

b. The correlational relationship between different theological sub-movements (descriptive, historical, systematic, and strategic practical) and praxis.

c. Types of practical-theological reflection as advanced by Elaine Graham, Heather Walton, and Frances Ward.

d. Local examples.

4. Political Theology and Liberation Theology as Dialogical Lenses

a. History and types of political theology and liberation theology.

b. Political theology and liberation theology as critical-prophetic witness of the church.

c. Emancipation and liberation as core themes for theologizing.

d. Local examples.

Core Section 2: Interdisciplinary Dialogical Platform to experiment on the ways for theology to engage concrete public issues. Around five public/current issues from the below area-list will be selected each year for the dialogue. Experts or/and experienced practitioners in different fields of practice will be invited to the platform to share with students their analyses of the respective public/current issues, while theological responses (philosophical, exegetical, historical, and practical) will be given by teachers from different sub-disciplines in theology. Students are expected to engage in the dialogue with the theories and concepts they learnt from core section 1, and with their own experience as a citizen. They will also be required to continue the discussion on the eLearning platform (Blackboard) which constitutes one of their homework assignments.

1. Land Use in Hong Kong; and, Land in the Hebrew Bible: The dialogue will focus on issues related to sustainability, conservation, development, environmental justice, and theologies of territory in the Hebrew Bible.

2. Poverty and Justice in Hong Kong; and, Church and the Struggle for Social Justice: The dialogue will focus on (a) the different ways (social scientific and theological) of describing, categorizing, explaining, and interpreting the phenomenon of poverty in Hong Kong; (b) how can the church build a movement of Christians committed to tackling poverty in Hong Kong?

3. Sex, Marriage and Family in Hong Kong; and, En-Gendering Theology: LGBT issues in Hong Kong will be critically discussed. Different ways of Christian responses will be examined.

4. Mainland-Hong Kong Relations; and Church-State Relations: The changing Mainland-HK relations amid integration and confrontation will be discussed. Beijing’s policy toward HK and the local reactions in the midst of socio-economic integration in the recent decade will be the focus. This changing phenomenon will be critically engaged with various theological perspectives of church-state relations.

5. Rule of Law in Hong Kong; and Rule of Law and Christian Traditions: “Is Hong Kong’s rule of law under threat?” “How is the rule of law to be understood, and understood in the local context?” “How shall we understand the biblical foundations for the rule of law in the Western world?” “How shall Christian communities respond to the concerned local debates?” These questions will form the focal concern of the dialogue.

6. Selected issues in Social Policy; and Christian Vision of a Good Society: one concrete issue regarding local social policy on housing, labor, social welfare, medical and health care, education, or social security, etc. will be selected for the dialogue. How Christian visions of a good society can engage in the debate will be examined.

7. Other Important Public Affairs that take place during the Teaching Period

courses.subject: THEO
courses.title: Clinical Pastoral Education
courses.description: Clinical Pastoral Education (CPE) is a mode of theological education that has a history of several decades. It facilitates pastoral growth through action-reflection mode of learning in clinical settings. This course requires students to complete one unit of CPE programme at a training center recognized by the Divinity School.
courses.enrollment_requirement: For students in Master of Divinity
courses.learning_outcomes:
1. Students begin to articulate the central themes of their religious heritage and the theological understanding that informs their ministry.

2. Students are equipped to identify and discuss major life events, relationships and cultural contexts that influence personal identity as expressed in pastoral functioning.

3. Students are able to initiate peer group and supervisory consultation and receive critique about one’s practice.

4. Students begin to acquire the basic skills to recognize relational dynamics within group contexts.

5. Students being to demonstrate integration of conceptual understandings presented in the curriculum into pastoral practice.

6. Students are equipped with basic skills and knowledge to initiate helping relationships within and across diverse populations.

7. Students begin to use the clinical methods of learning to achieve their educational goals.

8. Students are able to formulate clear and specific goals for continuing pastoral formation with reference to personal strengths and weaknesses.
courses.course_syllabus: Students will join a 400-hour Clinical Pastoral Education (CPE) training in hospital settings offered by a professional CPE center in collaboration with the Divinity School of Chung Chi College. The training programme involves the following elements: students setting their own learning goals, theory and practice integration clinical pastoral care, learning theological reflection in action, integration of medicine into theology, psychology and sociology. Students will attend lectures delivered by theological, medical, psychological professionals, do bedside pastoral care, learn clinical skills in pastoral care by various means, receive individual supervision, learn group dynamics in group supervision settings, review relevant readings, etc.
